__data__.text:
998                                               YANG Xi-wen et al.
© 2012, CAAS. All rights reserved. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
E. coli, and Salmonella enteritidis bacteria (la Ragione
et al. 2001, 2003).  Although fecal excretion of E. coli
and Salmonella was not directly measure d, results of
this study that supplementation o f B. subtilis  in f eed
significantly reduced E. coli and Salmonella and Shi-
gella counts in pond water also support the genera l
principle of t he compet itive exc lusion funct ion by
B. subtilis. On the other hand, practices of improving
fish and shrimp health and production performances in
aquacultures by using B. subtilis or PSB to improve
water quality (Gildberg et al. 1997; Zhang et al. 2008;
Zhao et al. 2008) also points to the necessit y of reduc-
ing harmful bacteria growth that thrives in warm water
temperatures in hot summer months.  In experiment 1,
treatment with PSB of pond water also si gnificantl y
reduced growth of E. coli and Salmonella and Shigella,
possibly through the mechanism of competin g for or-
ganic nutrients against the pathogenic bacteria.  Of in -
terest is the finding that Bacillus counts in water were
increased by feed supplementation of B. subtilis spores
alone, but reduced when the treatment was combine d
with PSB treatment in water.  This result also supports
the principle of competitive suppression of a wide spec-
trum of bacteria, apart from E. coli and Salmonell a
and Shigella, by PSB.  Thus, when fecal sheddin g of
E. co li and Salmonella and Shigella was re duced by
feed supplementation o f B. subtilis , subsequent treat-
ment of PSB in pond water maximally reduced the ex-
tent of growth of E. colif , Salmonella and Shigella, and
other bacteria.
Still another interestin g phenomenon was the unex -
pectedly low counts of Salmonellaand a Shigella bacteria,
and to lesser extent counts of E. coli and Bacillus, in
pond water on d 30, as compare d with samples taken
on other 2 samplin g occasions in experiment 1.  This
reduction of water bacteria counts was para lleled by
slight decreases in water LPS concentrations on d 30,
as compared to the LPS concentrations on d 15 and 45
of experiment 1.  These reductions coincided with the
occurrence of a typhoon storm, which provided a large
amount of fresh, clean rain water into the pond .
Nevertheless, gosling plasma LPS concentrat ions did
not decrease as did the bacteria and water LP S
concentrat ions, su ggesting that there was a t ime lag
effect between water bacteria counts an d water LP S
and plasma LPS concentrations.  This relationship be-
tween changes in water Gram-negative bacteria growth
and water and blood LPS concentrations was again dem-
onstrated at the end of experiment 2.  Specifically, there
was an increase an d then decrease of blood LPS con-
centration that occurred at a delay relative to that of
water bacterial growth and LPS concentrations.  An -
other discrepanc y between the two experiments wa s
the LPS concentrat ions in pond water.  T he LPS con-
centrations in experiment 1 were almost 10 times a s
high as those measure d in experiment 2, poss ibly due
to the very high gosling density on t he water surface
compared to that in experiment 2.  In addition, the lim-
ited area of water in pens in experiment 1 might restrict
water movement and self cleaning and lead to LPS ac-
cumulation in water.
Our previous studies have shown that enlarging flock
size or increasing water geese stocking density exacer-
bated bacteria growth and LPS contamination in pond
water (Jiang et al. 2011).  LPS, in turn, reduced geese
reproduction performances, including egg laying rate,
egg fertility and embryo livability (Jiang et al. 2011).
In addition, goslings produced from over-sized flocks
with high on water stockin g density were often low in
quality or livability, as evidenced by poor appetite, slow
growth rate and high mortality (Jiang et al. 2010).  The
water bacteria growth-related problems were the most
severe during hot summer months due to the high wa-
ter temperature, which boosts bacteria proliferation.  In
this stud y, the use of probiotic bacteria to competi-
tively reduce Gram-ne gative bacteria proliferation in
summer mont hs helped reduce LPS contam ination in
geese, and mitigated the summer-associated deteriora-
tions in geese reproductive performances.  Maintaining
sound reproductive performance in geese by reducing
LPS contamination may also produce good effects on
the number and qualit y of hatched goslings.  This i s
because LPS , e ither from in ovo or an exogeno us
source, adversely affected gosling immune function and
growth (Jiang et al. 2010).  This idea is supporte d by
the findings in exper iment 1 t hat demonstrate better
growth performance in goslings when LPS contamina-
tion was reduced b y probiotic competitive reduction.
In summary, in “goose-fish” integrative production
system, supplementation withB. subtilis spores in geese
feed, and application of photosynthetic bacteria in pond
water, both contr ibuted to re duced growt h of Gram-

© 2012, CAAS. All rights reserved. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
Improv ing Geese Pro duction Performance in “Goose-F ish” Pro duction System by Compet itive Re duction of Pat hogen ic                999
negative bacteria E. coli, Salmonella and Shigella, and
LPS concentrations in pond water, with the maxima l
effect ac hi eve d w hen t he two treatments wer e
combined.  Reductions in water bacteria growth an d
LPS concentrations helped to lower geese and gosling
plasma LPS concentrations, and helped to improve geese
repro duct ive performances an d gos li ng growt h
performances.  Therefore, feed supplementation of
B. subtilis spores and water treatment w ith photosyn-
thetic bacteria provide useful techniques for ecological
“water fowl-fish” integrative production.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Animals and treatments
Experiment 1  240 15-d old healthy Magang goslings of
the same genetic background, which had already been vac-
cinated aga inst av ian influenza an d gos ling p lague, were
purchased from a local breeding farm.  The birds were
equally allocated into 16 “yard and water” pens, eac h hav-
ing a space of 6 m2 sheltered yard on the land and 4 m2 on
pond water, with an average depth of 1 m.  The 16 pens
were arranged into a 2×2 factorial experimental design, with
th e ma in treatments being t he supp lementat ion o f
B. su btilis spores in t he grow ing an d fatten ing fee ds
(hereafter referre d as B. su btilis treatment), and addition of
PSB into pond water inside the pens (hereafter referred as
PSB treatment ).  Eac h treatment com bination was re pli-
cated by 4 pens w ith 15 goslings.  T he goslings were fe d
growing feed durin g phase I of the growth from a ges 15 to
30 d old, and fattening feed during phase II growth, o r
ages 31 to 60 d old.  Arranged within the experiment, phas e
I growth corresponded to the first 15 d of experiment, while
phase II growth thereafter.  Growin g and fattenin g fee d
pellets, containin g 20 and 15% crude protein, and 11.3 an d
10.3 MJ kg-1 metabolizable energy, respectively, were manu-
factured according to the formula in Table 2.  For B. subtilis
treatment, 150 g of B. subtilis spore product, C loSTATTM
11 Dry (Kemin Industries, China), was included into eac h
metric ton of growing or fattening feed.  For weekly PS B
treatment to the water, 20 mL of aqueous PSB concentrat e
(Guan gdong Shunde B lue Monta in B iotec hnology Lt d.,
Shunde, Guan gdong, China) was diluted with 100 times o f
water, set aside overni ght, and then evenl y poured into
the pond water within each pen.  Throughout th e
exper iment, goslings were fe d ad libitum , but were not
provided with additional drinking water except t he pon d
water inside the pens.  In addition to supportin g goslin g
activities, pond water was used to raise fish, which were
mainly Tilapia (Tilapia mossambic a), big head carp
(Aristichthys nobilis(( ), bream (Megalobrama termina lis),
and mud carp ( Cirrhinus molistorell a), at a total densit y
of 1 fry m-2 water surface at the spring (April) release.  Cul -
tivation of suc h fish types at suc h density is common ly
practiced, and thought to ut ilize gosling feces w ithout im-
pairin g geese production performances.
Every week the goslings were weighed to record live
weight.  On d 15, 30, and 45 of the experiment, water samples
were collected from each pen for analyses of bacteria counts
and LPS concentrations.  On the same da ys, blood sample s
from 2 birds in each pen were collected into tubes with
heparin and used for measurement of plasma LP S
concentrat ions.  B lood plasma was separate d by centr ifu-
gation for 20 min under 1 000×g, and frozen at -20°C unt il
analyses for LPS concentration.  On d 49 of experiment ,
after overnight fasting and weighing, 2 birds (1 male, 1
female) from eac h pen were humanely slaughtered and the
carcasses were evaluated for quality .
Experiment 21 160 breeding Magang geese of 4 years of
age were separate d into 2 f locks of equa l size.  T he flocks
were maintained on two adjacent standard “geese-fish”
integration un its, eac h cons isting of a geese house (250
m2), a yard (500 m2) and a fish pond (550 m2).  These ponds
were also used to raise fish, as described in experiment 1 .
The geese were induced to lay eggs out-of season by arti-
ficial photoperiod, and egg laying starte d in late May, pro -
ceeded into summer, and ended in autumn (October) .
Throughout the experiment, the geese were fed with a basal

flock was su pplemente d w ith B. su btilis s pore product,
which was mixed with rice grain prior to feeding and weekly

1. T he contro l f lock geese rece ived ne ither of t hese
probiotic bacteria treatments.  Every 20 d, 15 water sample s
were taken from each treatment pond for determination of
bacter ial counts an d LP S concentrat ions.  On t he same
occasions, blood samp les were ta ken from 15 geese fro m
each treatment f lock, for measurement of LPS concentra -
tions in blood.
Throughout t he duration of t he exper iment, eggs were
collected daily and incubated ever y 3 or 4 d, in the same

__data__.text:
1000                                                YANG Xi-wen et al.
© 2012, CAAS. All rights reserved. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
setters and hatchers (EI-40320, Qingdao Xingyi Electronic
Equipment Co. Ltd., China).  On d 7 of incubation, the egg s
were can dled to count fert ile e ggs an d to ca lculate e gg
fertilit y.  Upon hatchin g, the number of live goslings was
recorded for calculations of fertile e gg hatchabilit y and set
egg hatchabilit y.
Water bacteria counts
Pond water samp les were ana lyzed for t he Gram-ne gative
bacteria of t he ente robacte riaceae , E. coli , Salmone lla
and Shigell a, which are the most common Gram-negative
bacteria that contain LPS on the outer cell membrane (Raetz
and Whitfield 2002; Müller-Loennies et al. 2007 ).  Th e
samples were diluted 100-400 times with distilled H2O prior
to seeding on the MacConkey LB agar medium (Guangdong
HuangKa i Microbial Sci & Tech. Co. Lt d., China) plates.
Following overnight culture incubation at 37°C, colonie s
were counted an d E. co li bacteria counts in 1 mL water
samples were calculated by multiplying by the sample dilu-
tion factor.  Bacterial counts of Salmonell a and Shigell a
were s imilarly obtained, but by see ding the samp les ont o
Salmonella -Shigella agar medium (Guangdong HuangKai
Microbial Sci & Tech. Co. Lt d., China) plates.  Counts of
Bacillus were measure d by see ding t he diluted samp les
onto mannitol-egg yolk-polymyxin (MYP) agar plate ac -
cording to the method by He (1989).  Such obtained Bacil-
lus counts also contained B. cereus, as well as B. sutilis .
Measurement of LPS concentrations
LPS concentrat ions in plasma an d water samp les were de-
termined usin g the Diazotization Chromo genic Rea gent
Tachypleus amebocyte (horseshoe crab) Lysate A method ,
with the commercial assa y kit developed b y Fuzhou Xinbei
Biochemical Co., Ltd. (Fuzhou, China).  Briefly, 5 mL of the
sample was added into each well of a 96-well microplate,
followed by the addition of 20 µL of alkalinizing buffer to
prevent poss ibl e interference t hat cou ld ar ise from t he
proteins.  Fo llowing mixing and incubation at 37°C for 10
min, the react ion volume was expan ded into 50 mL by an
addition of 25 µL LPS-free H2O.  50 µL of pyrochrome re-
agent so lution, conta ining Tachypleus ame bocyte lysate
and the chromogenic substrate Boc-Leu-Gly-Arg-p-
nitroanilide, was added into each well.  The reactions incu -
bated at 37°C for 10 m in, during which time the LPS cata -
lyze d c leavage of a co lorless pept ide su bstrate in t he
Tachypleus amebocyte lysate.  The cleaved peptide, i n
turn, liberated the yellow molecule p-nitroanilide from t he
chromogenic substrate.  At this point, 50 mL of diazotiza-
tion solution containing NaNO 2, N-(1-naphthyl)-ethylene-
diamine (NEDA) and HCl was suspen ded into eac h reac -
tion well.  A prompt reaction between p-nitroanilide, NaNO2,
and NEDA produced a rose colored diazotized magent a
derivative which was read at 570 nm with a microplate reader
(Bio-Rad MODEL 680, Bio-Rad, Japan).  Reading at 570 nm
proport ione d to t he amount of LPS in t he stan dards o r
samples, therefore samp le LPS concentrat ions were ca lcu-
lated in reference to rea dings of t he stan dards.  T he assa y
measuring range was between 0.01 to 100 Eu m L-1, an d
intra- and inter-assay CV were both less than 12%.
Carcass quality analysis
After being slaughtered, geese were ana lyzed with carcas s
quality accor ding to t he proce dures set by Wang an d Yu
(2002).  Wei ghts of enviscerated and semi-enviscerate d
carcasses were recorded, as well as weights of breast and
leg muscles, and abdominal and subcutaneous fats.  Based
on t hese measurements, percenta ges of carcass to live
weight and semi-envisceration, and envisceration to car-
cass wei ght were calculated.  The percenta ge ratios o f
breast and leg muscles, and abdominal and subcutaneou s
fats to carcass weight were also calculated.
Statistical analysis
Data of water bacteria counts , LPS concentrations in water
and geese plasma, gosling feed intake, live weight, an d
carcass measurements in experiment 1 were analyzed b y
the GLM procedure (SAS ver. 8.01, SAS Institute Inc., Cary,
NC, USA).  The treatment means between the main factors ,
i.e., B. subtili s and PSB treatments , and season or times of
data recording, were compared using the Tukey’s
studentized range test.  To normalize variance, LPS con -
centration data were transformed into logarithms, and bac -
teria counts transformed into square roots, prior to
analyses.  E gg fertility, fertile and set egg hatchabilities of
the contro l and treate d geese f locks in exper iment 2 wer e
analyzed by the t-test for percenta ge data, for eac h time
point of egg incubation.
Acknowledgements
This work was supported by the National Natural Scienc e
Foundation of C hina (30871795 ), the Earmar ked Fund for
Modern Agro-In dustry Tec hnology Researc h System,
China (CARS-43-16), the Guangdong Provincial Scienc e
and Technology Research Grant, China (2010B020306004).

germination in the gastrointestinal tract. Applied and

__data__.text:
ELSEVIER Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
E[OLO61I:IIL 
mOOELLIn6 
Aquaculture pond ecosystem model: temperature and dissolved 
oxygen prediction - 
mechanism and application 
Steven D. Culberson, Raul H. Piedrahita * 
Department of Biological and Agricultural Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA 
Received 15 August 1994; accepted 26 April 1995 
Abstract 
Accurate characterization of temperature and dissolved oxygen stratification in ponds used for aquaculture is of 
critical importance in understanding how these ponds may be constructed, oriented, or otherwise managed 
biophysically when one wishes to provide optimal environmental conditions for the organisms being cultured. While 
field studies can provide characterizations of water quality stratification at a single locale, to date there have been 
few attempts at developing reliable models which can be used at a variety of sites after initialization with appropriate 
local geographic and atmospheric data. In conjunction with the Pond Dynamics/Aquaculture Collaborative Re- 
search Support Program (PD/A CRSP), the authors have developed a water quality model (the Aquaculture Pond 
Ecosystem Model, A.P.E.M.) which predicts temperature and dissolved oxygen stratification at several sites, 
including Thailand, Rwanda, and Honduras. Advances in model structure and reduction of data requirements 
relative to previous models reflect the desire to provide for culturists the ability to predict stratification events with 
commonly available data, obtained either by hand or from a simple weather station located at or near the pond site. 
Strategies used for dealing with the reduced data sets, and the associated assumptions made, are also presented. 
Lastly, a series of simulation runs is performed to assess the quantitative effects on temperature and dissolved 
oxygen concentration generated by varying pond depth and phytoplankton density input values. 
Keywords: Oxygen; Pond; Stratification; Temperature 
I. Introduction 
The science of aquaculture demands a wide 
range of skills and knowledge on the part of the 
culturist, particularly as the culture system is 
pushed to contain higher densities of animal and 
plant biomass and to produce increasing quanti- 
ties of high quality product. Paramount to this 
science is an accurate and reliable understanding 
* Corresponding author. Fax: (+ 1-916) 752-2640. 
of the culture environment itself - water quality 
requirements for the cultured species must be 
met and maintained (Allan and Maguire, 1991; 
Bejda et al., 1992). Aquaculture is carried out in 
a wide variety of systems, and ponds are the most 
common production systems on a worldwide ba- 
sis. Aquaculture ponds are normally less than 1.5 
m deep, and vary in size from under 100 m 2 to 
over 10 ha. Animals cultured in these ponds may 
be fed prepared diets, or the ponds may be 
fertilized to promote the production of food for 
0304-3800/96/$15.00 © 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved 
SSDI 0304-3800(95)00140-9

metadata.file_name: Aquaculture pond ecosystem model- temperature and dissolved oxygen prediction - mechanism and application.pdf
metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Aquaculture pond ecosystem model- temperature and dissolved oxygen prediction - mechanism and application.pdf

__data__.text:
232 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
the fish within the pond. Regardless of how the 
animals in a pond are fed, water quality is largely 
determined by biological and chemical processes 
related to photosynthesis and respiration by or- 
ganisms within a pond. Predicting and managing 
water quality in pond aquaculture presents spe- 
cial challenges due to the exposure of the system 
to factors of climate and topography. Since bio- 
chemical processes and organism growth rates 
are regulated to a large extent by temperature, 
and since the survival of the organisms within the 
pond environment depends principally upon the 
amount of available oxygen, pond water tempera- 
tures and dissolved oxygen (D.O.) levels are likely 
to be the most important items of concern to 
pond water quality management (Boyd et al., 
1978; Boyd, 1990). 
Inasmuch as animal mortality continues to oc- 
cur within the industry due to low D.O. incidents 
in rearing ponds, further understanding of D.O. 
dynamics within these ponds is essential, particu- 
larly if this understanding leads to qualitative 
and/or quantitative predictions of what these 
levels might be under given local atmospheric 
conditions. Since the practice of mechanically 
aerating ponds during periods of low D.O. is 
dependent upon supplying enough oxygen to ful- 
fill the respiratory needs of the animals and plants 
within the pond, and since there may be some 
time lag between when the aerators begin work- 
ing and when the oxygen supplied is fully mixed 
into the pond, prediction of the time of onset of 
low D.O. events would allow more efficient appli- 
cation of aerator usage. 
Shallow aquaculture ponds typically show daily 
patterns of temperature and oxygen stratification, 
rendering portions of these ponds unusable by 
the cultured animals. Stratification events ob- 
served in aquaculture ponds tend to be short 
lived, as ponds normally stratify during the day 
and destratify at night (Chang and Ouyang, 1988; 
Losordo, 1988). In ponds showing marked stratifi- 
cation, surface waters may be harmful to fish due 
to supersaturated D.O. conditions in combination 
with high temperatures, while in the same pond 
near anoxic conditions may exist close to the 
bottom (Krom et al., 1985; Chang and Ouyang, 
1988; Losordo, 1988; Boyd, 1990). 
Previous attempts to characterize temperature 
and dissolved oxygen patterns in ponds used for 
aquaculture are not common in the literature, 
and where they exist, most tend to be made using 
direct observations of the pond in question, use- 
ful only for predictions of nighttime D.O. decline, 
and/or are based on the assumption the pond 
water column is uniform over depth (Boyd et al., 
1978; Romaire and Boyd, 1979; Meyer and Brune, 
1982; Klemetson and Rogers, 1985; Madenjian et 
al., 1987). There are, however, several reports of 
models incorporating mechanistic characteriza- 
tion of the biochemical and physical processes in 
a pond which together govern the resulting tem- 
perature and D.O. levels (Cathcart and Wheaton, 
1987; Losordo, 1988; Losordo and Piedrahita, 
1991). While fairly accurate, these models are not 
very "user friendly", and require large, complete, 
and complex data sets for execution. 
The purpose of the study described below was 
to construct a mechanistic model (the Aquacul- 
ture Pond Ecosystem Model, A.P.E.M.) which 
capitalized on the understanding of the biologi- 
cal, chemical, and physical processes embodied in 
the more complex models cited above, while sim- 
plifying the data input needs so the resulting new 
model would be applicable to a broader range of 
shallow pond aquaculture sites where access to 
data is more limited. This study has updated 
information contained within the previous mod- 
els, taking into account more recent characteriza- 
tions of the biological and chemical processes 
occurring in the pond ecosystem. The model pre- 
sented in this paper was developed using a struc- 
ture similar to a previous model (Losordo, 1988; 
Losordo and Piedrahita, 1991), with considerable 
revision. It is hoped this revision and simplifica- 
tion will provide a predictive tool for farmers 
and/or for facility planners who may want to 
know how pond morphology, siting, and manage- 
ment techniques will affect temperature and dis- 
solved oxygen levels in any ponds built on a 
prospective site. 
The current model has been validated using 
data from the Pond Dynamics/Aquaculture Col- 
laborative Research Support Program database 
(PD/A CRSP, 1992), and this paper demon- 
strates the accuracy of the temperature and D.O.

S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 233 
predictions at a variety of aquaculture sites. A 
subsequent discussion is presented detailing the 
response of the coupled temperature and dis- 
solved oxygen model to various alterations of 
pond depth and phytoplankton concentration. 
2. Temperature 
A conceptual view of the pond water column 
as it is assumed to be for the purposes of the 
present model is presented in Fig. 1 (after 
Losordo et al., 1986). For the purpose of charac- 
terizing water column stratification, this concep- 
tual diagram has been chosen to have three water 
"volume elements" (termed "surface", "middle", 
and "bottom"), and one sediment/benthic vol- 
ume element. The thickness of each of the vol- 
ume elements will range from 0.3 to 0.5 m for 
typical aquaculture ponds of depth 0.9 to 1.5 m. 
It is the characterization of each of the processes 
depicted in Fig. 1 which forms the bulk of the 
working model. In addition, there are subroutines 
for calculating solar incidence angles, effective

234 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
NetEnergySurf

Fig. 2. STELLA IIQ diagram of energy-balance structure. 
wind fetch distances, etc., which can be thought 
of as "supporting" calculations - important in 
the execution and integration of all of the various 
model equations, but which are not calculations 
directly responsible for changes in temperature 
or dissolved oxygen levels. 
An assembly of the volume elements is con- 
structed in the vertical plane to account for dif- 
ferences in rate processes, diffusion, density, light 
penetration, etc., with depth in the simulated 
pond ecosystem. In all cases there is an assumed 
horizontal homogeneity within any given vertical 
volume element. This assumption is consistent 
with data presented in studies of vertical and 
horizontal temperature variation in ponds used 
for aquaculture (Cathcart and Wheaton, 1987; 
Losordo, 1988; Losordo and Piedrahita, 1991). 
When all the energy and mass balance pro- 
cesses important within the conceptual diagram 
are identified, the model's basic framework is 
constructed using STELLA IIl(High Performance 
Systems, Inc., 1990). Fig. 2 presents a schematic 
diagram for those elements used to calculate the 
energy balance in the water column. For the 
purposes of the present model, the following form 
of the net energy change in the pond ecosystem is 
used (WRE, 1968; TVA, 1972): 
~net =~)sn-{-~)at--~ws--(j~e~t-~Dc--(l~sn,z-{'-~sed 
- ~ -+ ~d,: (1) 
where: 
~net = net heat flux for the pond 
~'s. = penetrating short-wave solar irradiance 
(Eq. A1) 
q~at = net atmospheric radiation (Eq. A2) 
~bws = water surface back radiation (Eq. A3) 
~b e = evaporative heat transfer (Eq. 2) 
the = sensible heat transfer (Eq. A4) 
~b .... = solar irradiance at lower volume ele- 
ment boundary (Eq. A5) 
~bse d = heat transfer between sediment and bot- 
tom water volume elements (Eq. A6) 
~bg w = heat loss from sediment volume element 
to ground water table (Eq. A7) 
~bd, z = effective diffusion of heat at upper and 
lower volume element boundaries (Eq. A8) 
N.B. All heat flux terms in kJ/mZ/hr. 
In this generalized form of the heat flux equa- 
tion not all terms will be considered for each of 
the volume elements. There will be no ~bg w term 
for the surface or middle volume elements, for 
example, and there will be no ~b e term for the 
middle or bottom volume elements. Each of these 
heat flux elements and their mathematical de- 
scriptions as implemented in the current model, 
are shown in Appendix A. Revisions to previ- 
ously-used formulations (Losordo, 1988; Losordo 
and Piedrahita, 1991) are described below. 
2.1. Evaporative heat transfer 
Heat loss by evaporation from the pond sur- 
face involves a state change of water from liquid 
to water vapor. The energy required for this 
transformation through the latent heat of vapor- 
ization is taken from the energy stored within the 
water column (Moore et al., 1978; Orlob, 1981). 
This process is also influenced by the effects of 
wind across the surface of the pond, and by the 
moisture content in the air lying just above the 
water surface (Henderson-Sellers, 1984). Losordo 
and Piedrahita (1991) successfully employed the

__data__.text:
S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 235 
following estimation of evaporative heat flux fol- 
lowing studies by Fritz et al. (1980): 
qb e = NW2( es-ea) (2) 
where: 
N= empirical coefficient from Lake Hefner 
(Fritz et al., 1980)=5.0593 (kJ m -2 km -1 
mmHg- 1) 
W 2=wind speed 2 m above water surface 
(km/hr) 
e S = saturated vapor pressure at Twc (mmHg) 
e a = water vapor pressure above the pond sur- 
face (mmHg) 
In turn, e s and e a are approximated as (Fritz 
et al., 1980): 
e s = 25.374 exp(17.62 - 5271/Twc ) (3) 
e a = Rh* 25.374 exp(17.62 - 5271/T~c ) (4) 
where Rh = relative humidity measured 2.0 m 
above the water surface. 
Relative humidity measurements were not 
available from the PD/A CRSP Database (PD/A 
CRSP, 1992). Henderson-Sellers (1984) offers a 
slightly different estimation for water vapor pres- 
sure which uses dew-point temperature in place 
of relative humidity measurements: 
e a = 610.78 exp[17.2694* Ta~--~- 273.16 ]1 (5) 
where T d = dew-point temperature in K. 
While dew-point temperatures are rarely 
recorded for aquaculture pond sites, Koon et al. 
(1986) suggest average daily dew-point tempera- 
ture may be estimated by subtracting 2°C from 
the morning minimum dry-bulb temperature. This 
estimation, in combination with Eq. 5 shown 
above, is then incorporated into the present model 
to estimate evaporative heat flux. Accurate esti- 
mation of the magnitude of this heat flux is 
critical to an accurate simulation, as it accounts 
for up to one third of the total energy loss from 
the ponds studied (Culberson, 1993). 
2.2. Energy distribution within the water column 
The two processes responsible for energy dis- 
tribution in the water column (beyond those asso- 
ciated with light penetration and attenuation) 
are: (1) that concerning the distribution of energy 
due to molecular diffusivity and turbulent eddy 
diffusion, commonly considered together as "ef- 
fective diffusion" (dominant during warming peri- 
ods, see Eq. A8); and (2) that concerning the 
distribution of energy due to convective transport 
(dominant during cooling periods). Each of these 
processes is treated at length in Sundaram and 
Rehm (1973), Chapra and Reckhow (1983), Hen- 
derson-Sellers (1984), Losordo (1988), and 
Losordo and Piedrahita (1991). The choices of 
which estimation procedures to be included here 
closely follow those used by Losordo and 
Piedrahita (1991). 
2.3. Energy distribution by convective mixing 
During cooling periods convective mixing is 
the dominant mechanism for energy distribution 
within the water column, buoyant instabilities oc- 
cur (where cooler, denser surface waters lie above 
warmer, less-dense, layers), and convective trans- 
port mixes adjacent layers (Losordo, 1988; 
Losordo and Piedrahita, 1991). For the purposes 
of modeling this process of convective mixing the 
Sundaram and Rehm (1973) method has been 
incorporated here: during convective mixing 
events the effective diffusion coefficient between 
two adjacent volume elements is allowed to as- 
sume some maximum value. 
The value considered as the maximum effec- 
tive diffusion coefficient (Ema x) depends in large 
measure on the size of the time step used for 
model execution (Losordo and Piedrahita, 1991), 
and the present model adopts the value used by 
Losordo (1988): 6000 cruZ/hr. 
Implementation of the energy distribution co- 
efficients described above involves the compari- 
son of temperatures in adjacent volume elements 
in each simulation time step. If buoyant instabili- 
ties do not exist, energy movement is considered 
to occur by effective diffusion. If buoyant instabil- 
ities do exist, then energy movement is consid- 
ered to occur by convective mixing. 
2.4. Wind speed and wind uector adjustments 
A number of the equations used in calculating 
pond temperatures incorporate wind speeds at a

__data__.text:
236 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
given reference height above the pond surface 
(Eqs. 2, A1.2, A4 and A8.5). A simple adjustment 
function was developed and used by Losordo and 
Piedrahita (1991) after Pankofsky and Dutton 
(1984) so that wind speed data collected from any 
given height from the pond surface (up to a 
maximum of 10 meters) could be used as input to 
the model. In the present model this function is 
included in the equation: 
Wad j = Wz(10/z ...... )1/7 (6) 
where: 
W~a j =wind speed adjusted for anemometer 
height (m/s) 
W z = wind speed measured at height z (m/s) 
Zanemom = height of anemometer above pond 
surface (m) 
In addition, wind vectors could not be calcu- 
lated for the PD/A CRSP Database, since the 
PD/A CRSP data collection protocols do not 
include wind direction measurements. An esti- 
mate of wind vector magnitude is made, however, 
through a calibration run (see below). Once this 
calibration is made for a given data set with a 
given anemometer height, other wind 
speed/anemometer height measurements or in- 
puts are adjusted using the same calibration fac- 
tor. 
2.5. Wind direction and fetch adjustments 
Wind direction can have a significant effect on 
the extent of wind fetch across a water body 
(where pond width to length ratios are smaller or 
larger than one, for example), and some account- 
ing for the lack of these data must be made. Due 
to the relatively small size of the ponds simulated 
for the PD/A CRSP research sites (10 × 30 m, 
for example), it was assumed that in order for the 
effects of the winds to be at a maximum, the 
largest fetch length should be used. That is to say, 
in the absence of wind direction data, the winds 
were assumed to be blowing along the long axis 
of the ponds. In this way, then, any effects of 
wind fetch and wind shear are recognized in the 
model as having their maximum possible effect. 
Calibration of the model for wind vector magni- 
tude subsequently corrects for wind fetch and 
wind shear not being at their maximum (see be- 
low). 
2.6. Air temperature inputs 
The data reporting protocols for the PD/A 
CRSP experiment sites do not require continual 
monitoring of air temperatures throughout the 
diurnal cycle - only the daily minimum and maxi- 
mum air temperatures are recorded. Since air 
temperatures at the pond site are critical for 
calculations of convective heat exchange at the 
pond surface, evaporative heat loss, and atmo- 
spheric radiation into the pond, an estimation of 
air temperatures over the diel cycle is required. 
Card et al. (1976) developed a simulation algo- 
rithm which predicts air temperatures based on 
sinusoids derived from long-term weather data, 
initialized with minimum and maximum air tem- 
perature measurements. The temperature at any 
given time may be calculated: 
T= Tmean q- TempSwing* P (7) 
where: 
TempSwing = Tma x - Tmi n (°C) (8) 
Tmean = (Tma x -1- Tmin)/2 (°C) (9) 
P=a[sin(o)ltl-4)) + b sin2(o)ltl-qb)] (10) 
such that: 
P = temperature profile factor 
a, b = coefficients in temperature profile ex- 
pression (a and b set the amplitude of the 
temperature swing such that Pmax = 0.5, and 
peak to peak amplitude is unity. For use in the 
revised model minimum and maximum temper- 
atures are assumed to occur at 6:00 am and 
3:00 pm, respectively, or a = 0.4484, and b = 
0.2706; see Card et al. (1976) for detailed ex- 
planation) 
(.o 1 = angular frequency, 2~r/24 (radians/hr) 
t I = time (in hours from midnight) 
~b = phase angle (sets the profile correctly with 
respect to clock time; determined by the time 
at which the median temperature is expected

The use of Eq. 12 for the prediction of air 
temperatures at a given site provides one impor- 
tant means of reducing the data required for 
model execution. The two air temperature inputs 
used for this model (minimum and maximum 
readings for a given day) replace 1440 microlog- 
ger-recorded air temperature readings used by 
I_xgsordo and Piedrahita (1991). 
2. 7. Solar radiation inputs 
Since the entire energy balance description 
used in the model under discussion depends on 
estimations of energy flux into and out of the 
system, the most useful solar radiation input mea- 
surement would be in units of W/m 2. Indeed, 
where these measurements are available in the 
PD/A CRSP Database, they are entered directly 
into the model. However, the PD/A CRSP re- 
search sites had a research emphasis on phyto- 
plankton dynamics, and recorded photosyntheti- 
cally active radiation (PAR) only, measured as 
moles of photons/mZ/hr. Since the photometers 
measure only that radiation in the photosyntheti- 
cally active range of the spectrum (approximately 
420-750 nm), it is a measurement which underes- 
timates total radiation received by the earth in a 
particular location. For this reason, for those sites 
where only PAR measurements are available, an 
additional calibration and correction for solar 
irradiance values in W/m z is necessary. 
In addition, the collection of solar radiation 
data at PD/A CRSP sites is far less intensive 
than that utilized by Losordo and Piedrahita 
(1991). For use in the present model, solar radia- 
tion readings are taken at predetermined inter- 
vals (of between 2 and 4 hours) as cumulative 
totals, and hourly inputs of solar radiation are 
obtained by averaging the cumulative totals over 
the collection interval. In real terms, where 
Losordo and Piedrahita required up to 720 read- 
ings (one taken every minute over the course of a 
12-hour solar period) to generate inputs, sample 
data sets used for the present model require as 
few as five readings for data input generation. 
2.8. Temperature model calculation procedure 
As implemented in STELLA II (~ (High Per- 
formance Systems, Inc., 1990) and determined by 
the structure given to the present model, temper- 
ature calculations for each of the volume ele- 
ments involve tabulating the net heat flux for 
each element at each time step. This net heat flux 
is then added or subtracted from the previous 
time step temperature, and the current time step 
temperature is solved for. At the beginning of the 
simulation (time = 0) the temperature of each 
volume element is initialized with the 0600 hour 
(dawn) measured temperature, and each 
element's net heat content is set to zero. This 
procedure is explained in more detail in Losordo 
and Piedrahita (1991), although the calculation of 
the temperature of any volume element (Vii) at 
any time (t) is fairly straightforward: 
Tvi,t = Tvi,o -]- ( HVi,t_ 1 -[- ( d Hvi/ dt ) *dt) 
/p * Cpw * v i (13)

Tvi,, = temperature of Vii at time t (°C) 
Tvi,o = temperature of V/ at time t = 0 (°C) 
Hvi,t-a = heat stored in V// at time t - 1 (kJ) 
dHvi/dt = heat flux during the time interval 
(kJ/hr) 
dt = duration of the time interval (hr)

2.9. Input data summary and sample data set 
The data collection protocols at the PD/A 
CRSP research sites follow a fairly uniform 
cross-site pattern, particularly for those parame- 
ters which describe local atmospheric conditions 
(PD/A CRSP, 1992). In general, the data used 
for execution of the current model were collected 
at the following local times: 0600, 1000, 1400, 
1600, 1800, and 2300 hours each day. Not every 
parameter needed for model execution was mea- 
sured every day in every pond at a particular site, 
but several ponds at each site for each of several 
days were chosen for simulation since a data set 
complete enough for model initialization and exe- 
cution was available. Due to space limitations, 
however, only one pond per study site is pre- 
sented in this report, although the results de- 
picted below are representative of other ponds 
from each respective PD/A CRSP study site. 
A summary of the data inputs needed for 
execution of the temperature simulation portion 
of the model is presented in Table 1 for each of 
the PD/A CRSP research sites. The bulk of the 
data inputs are initialization terms. Only solar 
radiation and wind speed inputs are needed as 
input variables over the course of the simulated 
day. 
2.10. Calibration for use at PD /A CRSP sites 
Before the current model could be imple- 
mented using PD/A CRSP Database inputs, a 
calibration run had to be executed to obtain 
accurate, site-specific estimates for the relation- 
ship between wind speed and wind vector, and

irradiance. This calibration run was conducted 
for a given pond at each of the three PD/A 
CRSP research sites discussed (Honduras, 
Rwanda, and Thailand), and estimates were ob- 
tained for the site-specific parameters needed. 
The calibration run-derived values were then ap- 
plied to different ponds at each site and simula- 
tion results were generated for these novel ponds. 
The need for calibration of the present tempera- 
ture model would be removed if solar radiation 
inputs were for total solar irradiance in addition 
to PAR, and if in addition to wind speed, wind 
direction inputs were available. In all cases, the 
results presented below have been generated for 
ponds which have not received these specific cali- 
bration treatments. 
2.11. Simulation results from PD /A CRSP re- 
search sites 
2.11.1. Honduras 
Data for the execution of the present model 
for the E1 Carao Aquaculture Experiment Station 
in Comayagua, Honduras, were collected on Ju- 
lian Day 351 (December 17), 1990, and the pond 
simulated was #B7. Qualitatively, the timing of 
maximum stratification, the remixing of the water 
column after sundown, and the rate of nighttime 
cooling are well represented (Fig. 3). Quantita- 
tively, the model shows errors in its absolute 
predictions, although even when most inaccurate 
(in this case for the middle volume element), the 
model under-estimates temperatures according to 
a time lag function only. Even with this time lag 
error, over the course of the simulation predicted 
temperatures do not differ from measured tem- 
peratures by more than 1.0°C. 
2.11.2. Rwanda 
Data for the execution of the present model 
for the Rwasave Pond Dynamics/Aquaculture 
CRSP Research Site at Rwasave, Rwanda, were 
collected on Julian Day 146 (May 26), 1989, and 
the pond simulated was #C1. The surface and 
bottom layer temperatures are represented fairly 
closely, but there is some disagreement between 
measured and predicted middle volume element

2.11.3. Thailand 
Data for the execution of the present model 
for the Ayutthaya Station facility at Ayutthaya, 
Thailand, were collected on Julian Day 96 (April 
6), 1988, and the pond simulated was #12. There 
are inaccuracies for the prediction of individual 
temperatures at specific times, but the overall 
character of the simulation is close to what was 
measured in the pond (Fig. 5). The inaccuracies 
in the simulated output seem to reflect an overall 
underestimation of the amount of solar radiation 
throughout the 24-hour period. As with the other 
simulations presented here, the timing of peak 
stratification and remixing are closely predicted.

__data__.text:
S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 241 
stratification, and the resumption of isothermal 
conditions in the ponds are very closely pre- 
dicted. Less accurate were the prediction of indi- 
vidual temperatures at each hourly interval, al- 
though for the maximum stratification event the 
model was within 1.0°C for all three simulated 
ponds. 
2.13. D&cussion: Temperature 
What is most striking about the model simula- 
tions outlined here is the sustained accuracy of 
the predictions in temperature stratification (or 
lack thereof) across different pond sites in several 
geographic regions. Combined with increased 
flexibility of use and adaptability to less intensive 
input data files, it is evident the energy-balance 
approach used in these models is an appropriate 
one to use when characterizing the overall heat 
content within ponds used for aquaculture. The 
onset of stratification, the degree of stratification 
from surface to pond bottom, the onset of mixing, 
and the simulation of completely mixed condi- 
tions remain accurate. Differences in instanta- 
neous temperature predictions from measured 
temperature values across the pond depth rarely 
exceed 1.0°C, and are principally associated with 
a factor of time lag only. 
where: 
MO2net = net oxygen mass change for the vol- 
ume element 
MOzp =phytoplankton oxygen mass produc- 
tion (Eq. 15) 
MOzD = oxygen mass diffusing to/from atmo- 
sphere at surface (Eq. B1) 
MO2f = fish oxygen mass respiration (Eq. B2) 
MOzp r = phytoplankton oxygen mass respira- 
tion (Eq. 19) 
MO2wcr = water column oxygen mass respira- 
tion (Eq. 21) 
MOzs r = sediment oxygen mass respiration (Eq. 
22) 
MOzd,z = effective oxygen diffusion at depth z 
(Eq. B3) 
MO2x s = excess 0 2 demand by sediment on 
middle layer (Eq. 23) 
N.B. All oxygen mass transfer terms in mg 
O2/m3/hr. 
The elements of the oxygen mass flux pre- 
sented in Eq. 14 are shown diagrammatically in 
Fig. 1. Equations for each of these mass flux 
elements as implemented in the present model, 
are shown in Appendix B. Revisions of previously 
used formulations (Losordo, 1988) are described 
below. 
3.1. Phytoplankton oxygen production 
3. Dissolved oxygen 
As was the case with the temperature model 
outlined above, the correct modeling of dissolved 
oxygen concentrations in an aquaculture pond 
depends upon an accurate description of those 
factors contributing to oxygen entry into the pond, 
oxygen removal from the pond, and oxygen distri- 
bution within the pond. The form of the net 
oxygen change in the pond water column can be 
described as (Losordo, 1988): 
MO2net = MO2p --I- MO2D -- MO2f- MO2p r 
-- MO2wcr - MO2s r ___ MO2d,z -- MO2x ~ 
(14) 
In most ponds used for aquaculture (i.e. those 
that are fertilized and can be considered eu- 
trophic) phytoplankton provide the major source 
and sink for dissolved oxygen. The productivity of 
major phytoplankton species in the water column 
are affected by many factors, including: intensity 
of photosynthetically active solar radiation (PAR), 
water column light attenuation, water tempera- 
ture, pH and dissolved nutrient concentration. 
These characteristics have themselves been the 
focus of considerable study in limnology and 
aquacultural science, and will not be discussed at 
length here (see Losordo, 1980; Meyer, 1980; 
Wetzel, 1983; Smith and Piedrahita, 1988; Boyd, 
1990; Giovannini and Piedrahita, 1994). 
In estimating the rate of phytoplankton oxygen 
production, Steele's equation is commonly used

__data__.text:
242 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
to describe this process (see Losordo, 1988 for 
further treatment). Bannister (1974) presents 
Steele's equation as follows: 
MO2p = P * Chlorophyll - a concentration 
(mg/m 3) (15) 
P = (I/Imax)Pma x exp(1 - I/Ima×) (16) 
where: 
P = the rate of photosynthetic oxygen produc- 
tion (mg O2/mg Chl-a/hr) 
Pmax = maximum rate of oxygen production at 
light saturation (mg O2/mg Chl-a/hr) 
I = effective underwater PAR intensity 
(/.~mol/m2/hr) 
Im~ X = underwater PAR intensity at which light 
saturation occurs (/.Lmol/m2/hr) 
For use in the present model, Eq. 16 was 
integrated over depth such that (Meyer, 1980): 
Pvi = {[ Pmax exp(exp [ - ( I/Ima x) exp( - T/e Z 2)] 
-exp[- ( I/Imax)exp(-~ezl)])]} 
X {TIe(Z2 -- ZI)} -1 (17) 
where: 
Pvi = rate of photosynthetic oxygen production 
for volume element ~ (mg O2/mg Chl-a/hr) 
~Te = effective light extinction coefficient (m-l) 
z 1 = depth of the upper boundary of volume 
element V/ (m) 
z 2 = depth of the lower boundary of volume 
element V// (m) 
The inclusion of this form of the primary pro- 
ductivity equation for phytoplankton (Eq. 16) fol- 
lows closely the approach used by Losordo (1988). 
However, where Losordo conducted detailed pri- 
mary productivity studies to determine the values 
of Pmax and /max, the present model has used 
several modifications in order to estimate these 
values without resorting to extensive experimen- 
tal studies. 
In determining /max (the underwater PAR in- 
tensity at which light saturation occurs), the pre- 
sent model assumes that for locally adapted phy- 
toplankton populations no light inhibition occurs 
(Giovannini and Piedrahita, 1994). Therefore, the 
value used for /max for a given simulation run was 
set equal to the maximum PAR intensity recorded 
at the pond surface at a particular site for a given 
day. While this assumption may not be wholly 
accurate, Losordo (1988) noted during his studies 
that only rarely did the local solar regime exceed 
his measured light saturation intensities, and even 
then these intensities were found only in the very 
top of the water column and for very short peri- 
ods during maximum solar irradiance. 
The inclusion of some sort of substitute for 
Pmax is also needed for the model presented here, 
since the PD/A CRSP research protocols do not 
call for detailed primary productivity studies. The 
value of Pmax, however, is integral to the correct 
estimation of dissolved oxygen in aquaculture 
ponds, and can be the source of much error in 
D.O. prediction if it is estimated incorrectly. Epp- 
ley (1972) presents an estimation for a term Urea x 
which relates oxygen production to the rate of 
carbon fixation by the phytoplankton. The value 
of the carbon:chlorophyll-a ratio was initially 
found from limits listed in Reynolds (1984), and a 
calibration for the exact value of carbon/chloro- 
phyll-a was conducted based on the known dis- 
solved oxygen regime for a given pond. The val- 
ues obtained for the ratio of carbon to chloro- 
phyll-a fall well within the range of values re- 
ported in Lee et al. (1991). The following relation 
is used in the present model for estimation of 
emax : 
Pmax = (Carbon/Chlorophyll - a) * Urea x (18) 
where: 
Carbon/Chlorophyll-a = 12.5-50 (from 
Reynolds, 1984; calibrated for a given site and 
day) 
Uma x = temperature-dependent maximum spe- 
cific primary production rate (mg O2/mg C/hr; 
from Eppley, 1972) 
3.2. Phytoplankton photorespiration 
Respiration of the phytoplankton during pho- 
tosynthesis has commonly been represented as 
some proportion of the rate of photosynthesis 
(Meyer, 1980; Losordo, 1988). While the present 
model retains this somewhat crude assumption, 
new evidence on phytoplankton respiration rates 
provides a modification over the characterization

__data__.text:
S.D. Culberson, R. H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 243 
offered previously. Giovannini (1994) reported 
the presence of a time lag between the beginning 
of the dark period (sundown) and the time at 
which the phytoplankton respiration rate returns 
to the baseline nighttime respiration rate. Based 
on Giovannini's preliminary studies using high- 
resolution, rapid-response oxygen probe studies 
of phytoplankton populations, the time lag in the 
present model is represented as three hours. 
The rate of photorespiration is considered to 
be 10% of the rate of photosynthetic oxygen 
production (after Meyer, 1980 and Losordo, 
1988): 
MOzp r = 0.10(MOzv; DELAY 3.0 hr) (19) 
where: 
MO2p r = rate of D.O. respiration by phyto- 
plankton (mg O2/m3/hr) 
MOzp = rate of photosynthetic production by 
phytoplankton (mg O2/m3/hr) 
DELAY 3.0 hr = the time lag component 
3.3. Water column respiration 
The water column respiration rate (WCRR) is 
defined in the current model as that rate of 
respiration exhibited by the pond water column 
not explicitly considered separately (Losordo, 
1988). Included in this category are base respira- 
tion of the phytoplankton (dark respiration), zoo- 
plankton respiration, and respiration by sus- 
pended bacteria. Estimations of this water col- 
umn respiration rate are most conveniently made 
using dark bottle incubations of water sampled 
from the water column. For use in this model, 
however, a slight revision of these estimations 
was made due to the fact that different water 
column respiration rates could be calculated de- 
pending on what time of day the samples were 
collected, and on how long the dark bottles were 
incubated (Teichert-Coddington and Green, 
1992). In this revision, a regression equation was 
generated from Teichert-Coddington and Green's 
data which related 4-hour, daytime-collected dark 
bottle measurements of water column respiration 
rates to those rates measured by 4-hour, night- 
time-collected dark bottle tests. In effect, the 
daytime-collected measurements overestimated 
the water column respiration rates seen during 
the nighttime hours. For the PD/A CRSP sites, 
dark bottle estimations for nighttime water col- 
umn respiration were calculated using darkbottle 
measurements obtained during the daytime, ad- 
justed by the regression equation outlined above. 
In addition, the water column respiration rate 
was adjusted according to temperature (Krenkel 
and Novotny, 1980) by: 
kT1 = kT2 * 0 (TI- T2) (20) 
where: 
k:rl = reaction rate at temperature T 1 
kT2 = known reaction rate at temperature T 2 
0 = thermal coefficient (1.049; see Losordo, 
1980) 
As implemented in the present model water 
column respiration is calculated as: 
MOzwcr = MOzwcr m , 1.049 O'w~- to,) * 1000 (21) 
where: 
MO2wcr = WCRR of volume element, adjusted 
for temperature (mg O2/m3/hr) 
MOzwcr m = measured WCRR (mg O2/I/hr) 
T m = temperature at which WCRR was mea- 
sured (°C) 
There are, however, frequent cases where no 
dark bottle measurements of water column respi- 
ration rates were available in the PD/A CRSP 
Database. In these cases, water column respira- 
tion rates are determined from the nighttime 
decline in oxygen levels within the pond, and a 
respiration term has been used which was derived 
from a posteriori knowledge of the effect of this 
respiration on dissolved oxygen levels in the pond. 
The approach is less than ideal, but was useful in 
testing the methodology and mechanistic accu- 
racy of the revised model and not its absolute 
predictive accuracy. What is hoped is that the 
testing and validation of the model will reveal an 
overall robustness and generality of the charac- 
terizations of the physical, chemical, and biologi- 
cal processes contained within the model, and 
that the extension of these characterizations to 
novel situations would have logical, accurate un- 
derpinnings. Once the model has proven its abil- 
ity to mimic current or historical aquaculture

__data__.text:
244 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
situations, it can be used to examine future or 
"imagined" situations. 
3.4. Sediment respiration 
Losordo's previous mechanistic water quality 
model (Losordo, 1988) initializes the sediment 
respiration rate component using measured sedi- 
ment respiration rates, and subsequently adjusts 
that rate using the temperature correction factor 
as in Eq. 20. This rate was considered to be 
constant over the entire pond bottom, and admit- 
tedly was ill-defined. The PD/A CRSP research 
sites do not routinely report sediment respiration 
rates. Therefore, the nighttime dissolved oxygen 
decline estimation for water column respiration 
rates is considered to include that respiration 
exhibited by the pond bottom sediments as well. 
One slight modification to the estimation of 
sediment respiration was made, however, in light 
of recent work by fellow PD/A CRSP re- 
searchers, and others (Madenjian, 1990; Szyper et 
al., 1992). Where sediment respiration rates were 
measured and not included in the water column 
respiration term, and where dissolved oxygen lev- 
els fall below a certain threshold value (1.0 mg/1), 
sediment respiration was assumed to decline to 
zero. When this assumed threshold value was 
omitted in the Losordo (1988) and present mod- 
els, the lowest layer of the pond volume element 
was frequently simulated as becoming anoxic, 
even when the measured values in the pond for 
this layer were 1.0 mg/1 or more. 
As implemented in the present model sedi- 
ment respiration is calculated as: 
MO2s r = (MO2msr • O(Twc-Tm))/Yhs (22) 
where: 
MOzs r = sediment respiration rate, adjusted for 
temperature (mg O2/m3/hr) 
MO2msr = measured sediment respiration rate 
at measured temperature (mg O2/mZ/hr) 
0 = thermal coefficient for benthic oxygen de- 
mand (1.065; Krenkel and Novotny, 1980) 
Th~ = thickness of sediment volume element 
(m) 
Following the example set by Losordo (1988), 
the present model also accounts for excess sedi- 
ment respiration resulting from the diffusion of 
organic substances released into the overlying 
water column by the benthic bacteria and other 
processes contributing to oxygen demand. When 
the D.O. declines to zero in the bottom water 
volume element, the upward diffusion of these 
organic substances may exert an additional oxy- 
gen demand on the next higher volume element 
(in the present model, the middle volume ele- 
ment). This excess sediment respiration (in the 
middle volume element) is calculated as (Losordo, 
1988): 
MO2x s = - (MO2p,bot + MO2d,z ) 
+ MOzs r * (Ths/( Z,b -- Zub)) (23) 
where: 
MOzx s = excess sediment oxygen demand (mg 
O2/m3/hr) 
MO2p,bot=photosynthetic oxygen production 
for the bottom volume element (mg O2/m3/hr) 
MO2d,~ = effective diffusion from middle vol- 
ume element to bottom volume element (mg 
O2/m3/hr) 
Zub = depth of the upper boundary of the bot- 
tom volume element (m) 
Zlb = depth of the lower boundary of the bot- 
tom volume element (m) 
If the D.O. concentration of the bottom vol- 
ume element is calculated to be greater than 
zero, the value MO2× s is set to zero. 
3.5. Dissolved oxygen model calculation procedure 
In parallel with the calculation of model tem- 
perature outputs described above, dissolved oxy- 
gen calculations for each of the volume elements 
involves tabulating the net oxygen change for 
each element at each time step (Eq. 14). The net 
oxygen change is then added to or subtracted 
from the previous time step's oxygen mass, and 
the current time step oxygen concentration is 
solved for. Dissolved oxygen concentrations can 
be calculated for any volume element (V/) at any 
time (t) as: 
DOvi a = DOvi,t_ , + (dDOvi/dt) *dt) (24)

where: 
DOvi,t = D.O. concentration of V~ at time t 
(mg/1) 
DOvi,t_ 1 =D.O. concentration of V/ at time 
t - 1 (mg/1) 
dDOvi/dt = rate of change in D.O. concentra- 
tion in V/ during the time interval (mg/1/hr) 
3.6. Input data summary and sample data set 
The dissolved oxygen model uses as inputs 
data collected during routine collection protocols 
at PD/A CRSP research sites. A summary of the 
data inputs needed for execution of the dissolved 
oxygen portion of the model is given in Table 3. 
All of the input values for the dissolved oxygen 
component of the present model are those values 
used for initialization. No time-series data be- 
yond those used for the temperature simulations 
are needed to produce predictions of dissolved 
oxygen concentrations in the pond chosen for 
simulation. 
3. 7. Calibration for use at PD /A CRSP sites 
Unlike the calibration method used in the de- 
velopment of the temperature model, the calibra- 
tion of the dissolved oxygen model was necessar- 
ily pond specific - that is, while the solar radia- 
tion and wind vector variables could be calibrated 
using any pond on a given site (assuming these 
factors are uniform over the whole site), calibra- 
tion for biologically-dependent factors is depen- 
dent on the unique biochemical characteristics of 
each individual pond. Typically, phytoplankton 
populations show high variability in density from 
pond to pond, and may also exhibit varying effi- 
ciencies of primary production due to differences 
in nutrient availability, light penetration, and 
temperature stratification. 
As mentioned, a calibration was needed for 
the carbon : chlorophyll-a ratio. In the absence of 
detailed primary productivity studies including 
carbon:chlorophyll-a ratios like those conducted 
by Losordo (1988), no acceptable substitute for 
this calibration could be found. While this cali- 
bration reduces the model's ability to make a 
priori predictions of D.O. stratification in ponds 
used for aquaculture, it does not lessen the 
model's usefulness in examining the biochemical 
mechanisms which determine dissolved oxygen 
dynamics. The results obtained from the dis- 
solved oxygen model following this pond-specific 
calibration at each of the PD/A CRSP research 
sites are presented below. 
3.8. Simulation results from PD /A CRSP research 
sites 
3.8.1. Honduras

model for the E1 Carao Aquaculture Experiment 
Station were collected on Julian Day 351 (De- 
cember 17), 1990, for Pond #B7 (Table 3). The

3.8.3. Thailand 
Data for the execution of the dissolved oxygen

The character of the dissolved oxygen dynamics 
in all three volume elements is captured well, and 
the hourly predictions of D.O. concentration are 
very close to the measured values. The accuracy 
of the Thailand simulation run may be related to 
the overall completeness of the Ayutthaya Station 
portion of the PD/A CRSP Database.

__data__.text:
248 S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 
onset of stratification, the timing of maximum 
stratification, and the resumption of fully-mixed 
conditions within the ponds at all three sites are 
closely predicted. Less accurate were the predic- 
tions of individual dissolved oxygen levels in the 
volume elements at each hourly interval, although 
for the maximum stratification events, the model 
was within 1.13 mg/l of oxygen, averaged over 
the three ponds. 
3.10. Discussion: Dissolved oxygen 
The predictive accuracy of the dissolved oxy- 
gen model remains quite high in spite of the 
mass-balance modifications and model simplifica- 
tions. While there are some slight differences 
between the measured and modelled dissolved 
oxygen concentrations from the PD/A CRSP ex- 
perimental sites in terms of absolute values, the 
qualitative nature of the model outputs mimic 
quite well those dynamics encountered within the 
ponds - the timing of oxygen peaks, the magni- 
tude of the peaks, the extent of oxygen stratifica- 
tion, and the simulation of anoxic conditions near 
the bottom of the pond are all represented quite 
accurately. 
The present model, initialized and calibrated 
with fairly simple and easily-obtainable weather 
and water quality data, can be a reliable tool to 
be used when trying to understand if changes in 
pond management or morphology will have quali- 
tative and/or quantitative effects on dissolved 
oxygen levels within the pond. Also important to 
note is the robustness of the model when simulat- 
ing ponds located in different parts of the world: 
the outputs presented here range from coastal to 
inland tropical regions, and from elevations near 
sea level to the mountains of East Africa (eleva- 
tion 1700 meters). 
4. Simulation experiments 
Using the Aquaculture Pond Ecosystem Model 
(A.P.E.M.) described above, a series of simula- 
tion runs were conducted to investigate the ef- 
fects of different management strategies on pond 
temperature and dissolved oxygen regimes. The 
baseline run used was that for the Thailand PD/A 
CRSP site described previously (Tables 1 and 3). 
Pond depth and secchi disk depth (S.D.D.) for 
the baseline run were 0.96 m and 0.35 m, respec- 
tively. The model was used to examine the effect 
on dissolved oxygen and temperature stratifica- 
tion of changes in pond depth and secchi disk 
depth. The model was run for pond depths of 
0.48 m, 0.96 m, and 1.92 m, and for secchi disk 
depth to pond depth ratios of 0.25, 0.50, and 1.0. 
Secchi disk depth measurements are frequently 
used to estimate phytoplankton density in aqua- 
culture ponds (at least on a relative basis), and 
changes in S.D.D. represent changes in phyto- 
plankton concentration. Since phytoplankton 
density is assumed to be the most important 
factor influencing pond D.O. concentrations 
(which implicitly incorporates management prac- 
tices such as fertilizer application rates, water 
exchange frequencies, cropping effects associated 
with fish feeding, etc.), the results generated by 
the A.P.E.M. may therefore be thought of as 
indicative of overall pond behavior, and can be 
assumed to apply more generally to ponds other 
than the baseline pond selected for illustration 
here. Details of the simulation runs executed are 
examined below. 
4.1. Secchi disk depth/phytoplankton density ra- 
tios 
Changes in secchi disk depth are assumed to 
correlate with changes in the density of the phy- 
toplankton standing crop. In order to develop 
reasonable estimates of phytoplankton crop den- 
sity for each of the hypothetical S.D.D. inputs, a 
simple regression was made for the pond under 
scrutiny using measured values of S.D.D. and 
phytoplankton density taken on other dates from 
this pond (PD/A CRSP, 1992; Fig. 9). The re- 
gression only holds for S.D.D. measurements 
shallower than approximately 0.44 m. Where the 
hypothetical S.D.D. measurements used as inputs 
to the model exceed 0.44 m, the phytoplankton 
densities (expressed as concentration of chloro- 
phyll-a) are reduced to a default value of 5.0 
mg/m 3. The use of a default value of 5.0 mg/m 3 
chlorophyll-a for all S.D.D.s greater than 0.44 m

in effect implies that as S.D.D. increases beyond 
0.44 m, non-algal turbidity decreases. The deeper 
S.D.D. values used (0.48 m, 0.96 m, and 1.92 m) 
are therefore associated with lower concentra- 
tions of dissolved and non-algal particulate sub- 
stances that may absorb light. 
4.2. Simulation results: Temperature 
The temperature results from the simulations 
discussed are shown in Figs. 10-12. The most 
thermally-homogeneous pond generated through 
the simulations is that with a shallow depth (0.48 
m) and a correspondingly deep S.D.D. (0.48 m) 
(Fig. 10c). It is unlikely, however, that this pond 
would be useful in aquaculture, since the low 
phytoplankton density would also reflect low food 
availability for herbivorous culture animals. An- 
other difficulty with such a management scheme 
(0.48 m pond depth; 0.48 m S.D.D.), is the likeli- 
hood of rooted macrophytes invading the pond, 
which ultimately may prove costly to eradicate or 
control. Nearly as homogeneous as this pond is 
the pond depicted in Fig. 10b, where pond depth 
is 0.48 m and S.D.D. is 0.24 m, a simulation 
which combines a relatively shallow pond with a 
moderate phytoplankton bloom. This shallow 
depth and moderate phytoplankton density seems 
to provide sufficient conditions for minimizing 
temperature stratification, while at the same time 
maximizing overall primary productivity. A draw- 
back of this pond depth and S.D.D. combination 
is the uniformly high temperature reached in the 
pond. Deeper ponds may reach similar surface 
249 
temperatures but tend to have cooler tempera- 
tures in deeper waters. 
In general, the shallower ponds are less strati- 
fied than the deeper ponds (Fig. 10 versus Figs. 
11 and 12), and the more turbid ponds are more 
stratified than clearer ones (Figs. 10a, lla, and 
12a). This is in agreement with what is expected, 
given the light extinction coefficients associated 
with the various turbidities (expressed as S.D.D.). 
The pond represented in Fig. 12a (pond depth 
1.92 m; S.D.D. 0.48 m) shows the pond remaining 
stratified over the 24-hour simulation period, a 
phenomenon associated with larger, deeper bod- 
ies of waters such as lakes (Goldman and Horne, 
1983) - this corresponds to what one might ex- 
pect given a deeper water column and a relatively 
shallow S.D.D.

4.3. Simulation results: Dissolued oxygen 
The D.O. results from the simulations outlined 
above are shown in Figs. 13-15. For the pond 
with the simulated depth of 0.48 m, the interme- 
diate situation (Fig. 13b), where S.D.D. is 0.24 m, 
yields the most satisfactory results, both in terms 
of limiting D.O. stratification during the middle 
of the simulated day and in maximizing total 
primary productivity for the simulated 24-hour 
period. The most-dense phytoplankton case for 
this pond (Fig. 13a) shows some detrimental ef- 
fects caused by net phytoplankton respiration in 
the bottom layer of the pond (since it is likely the 
phytoplankton in this layer are light-limited), 
which also has the effect of lowering the net 
oxygen production of the pond (represented by 
the D.O. after the 24-hour simulation: approxi- 
mately 5 mg/1 in Fig. 13a and 6 mg/l in Fig. 
13b). Conversely, for the lowest phytoplankton 
density (Fig. 13c), there is negative net oxygen 
production within the pond. In this last case 
there does not seem to be enough phytoplankton 
in the pond to provide for the oxygen needs 
included in the various respiration terms. 
For the pond of simulated depth equaling 0.96 
m and S.D.D. of 0.24 m (Fig. 14a), the dissolved 
oxygen profiles are similar to those of the base- 
line run. In general, this configuration (0.96 m 
pond depth and 0.24 m S.D.D.) results in the 
most stratified D.O. levels - up to a 7 or 8 mg/l 
difference between the surface and bottom lay- 
ers. This configuration could have considerable 
effect on the ability to maximize production of 
bottom-dwelling species like shrimp. For the 
less-dense phytoplankton densities in this pond

water increases (signified by lower S.D.D), so 
does the tendency for stratification. In the analy- 
sis presented here, a low S.D.D. is associated 
with high concentrations of phytoplankton. These 
phytoplankton are net oxygen producers when 
they receive adequate amounts of light (close to 
the surface of the pond), but can become net 
oxygen consumers in deeper areas of the pond 
where oxygen production is insufficient to meet 
the respiratory needs of the plankton. 
Of the pond configurations tested, a pond with 
a depth of 0.48 m and a S.D.D. of 0.24 m resulted 
in the highest net oxygen production and the 
least temperature and D.O. stratification. This 
configuration contrasts with the measured values 
for the Thailand pond used as a reference for the 
simulations (0.96 m depth and 0.35 m S.D.D.). 
One characteristic of particular note, however, is

4.4. D&cussion." Simulation experiments 
Results obtained from the simulations pre- 
sented here represent the effects of pond depth 
and turbidity changes on temperature and dis- 
solved oxygen regimes in aquaculture ponds. As 
can be seen in Figs. 10 through 15, the tendency 
and stability of stratification increases as pond

the large temperature fluctuation within the pond 
over the 24-hour simulation cycle (Fig. 10b). This 
pattern of large temperature fluctuations is ob- 
served in all the shallow ponds when compared to 
deeper ponds having similar S.D.D. values. These 
larger temperature fluctuations are due to the 
smaller total thermal mass of water in the shal- 
lower ponds. Similarly, a low S.D.D. value for a 
given pond depth results in more marked overall 
stratification and higher temperature fluctuations 
in the surface layer of the pond. In general, as 
pond depth and S.D.D. increase, so does the 
overall uniformity in water temperature. Con- 
versely, for a given S.D.D., deeper ponds tend to 
stratify more than shallower ponds. 
For ponds with equal ratios between pond 
depth and S.D.D. (e.g. Figs. 10a, 11a, and 12a), 
increases in depth result in lower temperatures in 
the surface layer, but in more stable stratification. 
For example, where temperature uniformity for 
the 0.48-m-deep pond with a S.D.D. of 0.12 m 
(Fig. 10a) was reached at approximately 1700 
hours local time, the equivalent but deeper pond 
in Fig. 12a (1.92 m deep, 0.48 m S.D.D.) re- 
mained stratified until 0500 hours the next day, 
the end of the simulation period. 
The amount and distribution of oxygen pro- 
duced in the water column depends on light 
intensity and penetration, as well as on phyto- 
plankton concentration. The empirical relation- 
ship between light penetration (S.D.D.) and phy- 
toplankton concentration used in the simulations 
presented here is shown in Fig. 9. A residual 
phytoplankton concentration of 5 mg/m 3 (as 
chlorophyll-a) was assumed for S.D.D. values 
greater than 0.44 m as explained above. As a 
result of this assumption, ponds simulated with a 
S.D.D. of 0.48, 0.96, and 1.92 m were considered 
to have a phytoplankton chlorophyll-a concentra- 
tion of 5 mg/m 3. Dissolved oxygen concentration 
and stratification in the ponds varied with both 
pond depth and S.D.D. (Figs. 13-15). Dissolved 
oxygen in the bottom layer, and overall oxygen 
fluctuation over the diel cycle were highest in the 
0.48-m pond. By contrast, D.O. in the bottom 
layer reached zero for two of the S.D.D. tested 
with the 1.92-m-deep pond (Fig. 15a and b). In 
the shallow pond, an increase in S.D.D. from 0.12 
to 0.24 m resulted in a decrease in stratification, 
and increases in both the peak D.O. concentra- 
tion and overall oxygen production for the 24-hour 
cycle (Fig. 13a and b). Further increasing the 
S.D.D. resulted in a drop in phytoplankton con- 
centration to 5 mg/m 3 chlorophyll-a, and an 
overall drop in D.O. production. Dissolved oxy- 
gen concentration in the 0.48-m-deep pond with a 
S.D.D. of 0.48 m was therefore lower than for the 
other two S.D.D. values used (Fig. 13a, b and c). 
D.O. stratification was most marked in the 
0.96-m pond with a S.D.D. of 0.24 m (Fig. 14a). 
The dissolved oxygen difference between surface 
and bottom layers reached approximately 8 mg/1, 
and remixing of the layers occurred late in the 
day for the surface and middle layers (1800 hours 
local time), and in the early morning for the

__data__.text:
S.D. Culberson, R.H. Piedrahita / Ecological Modelling 89 (1996) 231-258 253 
bottom layer (about 0200 hours). Dissolved oxy- 
gen concentration in the bottom layer of the 
0.24-m-S.D.D. pond (Fig. 14a) reached its lowest 
value shortly after midnight, and just prior to 
mixing with the layers above it. The timing of the 
low D.O. values in the bottom layer is particularly 
important for shrimp and other benthic animal 
culture systems. 
Dissolved oxygen concentrations in the 0.96-m 
pond was lowest for 0.48 m S.D.D., and increased 
slightly when S.D.D. increased to 0.96 m (Fig. 14b 
and c). This rise is caused by the increase in 
oxygen production caused by the improved light 
penetration with the same phytoplankton concen- 
tration of 5 mg/m 3 chlorophyll-a, and with the 
same sediment and fish oxygen demand in both 
cases. 
Dissolved oxygen production in the 1.92-m 
pond was low for all S.D.D. values tested due to 
the low phytoplankton concentration (Fig. 15a, b 
and c). The bottom layer in the ponds with S.D.D. 
values of 0.48 and 0.96 m did not mix with the 
middle layer, and became anaerobic sometime 
during the night (Fig. 15a and b). By increasing 
the S.D.D. in this pond to 1.92 m, an increase in 
oxygen concentration in the pond was obtained 
due to the rise in light penetration and the drop 
in non-algal turbidity while maintaining constant 
phytoplankton chlorophyll-a concentration. While 
a moderate degree of stratification was observed 
in the 1.92-m-deep, 1.92-m-S.D.D. pond, dis- 
solved oxygen concentration remained low 
throughout the diel cycle, never reaching above 6 
mg/l, and dropping to just under 2 mg/l at the 
end of the 24-hour simulation. 
The low D.O. values in the shallow pond (0.48 
m) with a high S.D.D. (0.48 m; Fig. 13c), when 
compared to other ponds with S.D.D. equal to 
their pond depths (Fig. 14c and Fig. 15c), was the 
result of the low overall oxygen production rela- 
tive to the demand by the sediments and fish 
crop, which were the same for all the ponds 
tested. By increasing the depth of the pond and 
of the S.D.D., and maintaining phytoplankton 
chlorophyll-a concentration at 5 mg/m 3, the 
overall oxygen production was increased. This 
increase resulted in a rise in the D.O. available 
and in the D.O. concentrations in the ponds. 
5. Conclusions 
The results from this Aquaculture Pond 
Ecosystem Model should not be applied unre- 
servedly across all aquaculture sites. This model 
and these simulations are an attempt to quantify 
the chemical, physical, and biological processes 
occurring within an aquaculture pond, and then, 
having achieved an approximation of the pond 
ecosystem (the working model), make certain rea- 
sonable changes in inputs and functions to inves- 
tigate the probable effects these changes may 
have on the culture ecosystem. Model outputs 
illustrate the complexity of responses that result 
from simple changes in pond management pa- 
rameters; depth and S.D.D. in this case. The 
situations presented represent a particular com- 
puter "experiment". Similar experiments can be 
conducted for other situations prior to carrying 
out field trials. The speed, ease, and inexpensive 
nature of using a model should appeal to anyone 
interested in making better use of resources when 
striving for improved aquaculture methods and 
management techniques. This model does not 
presume to replace the careful experimentation 
performed every day by practicing aquaculturists, 
but does provide a complement to these efforts. 
Making models and asking hypothetical questions 
(which should, after all, arise during the culture 
cycle anyway) is one way to reduce the cost and 
time involved in refining our management tech- 
niques. The use of pond ecosystem models could 
drastically reduce the need for lengthy experi- 
mental trial culture cycles by more closely focus- 
ing on what the optimum culture conditions for a 
given site might be, as suggested by simulation 
results. 
The simplifications made within the present 
model and the increased user-friendliness with 
which it is constructed make available a basic 
pond ecosystem model which can incorporate 
more accurate characterizations of phytoplankton 
physiology and pond ecosystem behavior, as these 
characterizations become available. This basic 
temperature and dissolved oxygen model also 
provides a framework into which may be added 
characterizations of pH, alkalinity, nutrient dy- 
namics, and ultimately fish yield.

Appendix B. Dissolved oxygen model equations 
Equations as used by Losordo (1988) and in- 
cluded in the present model. The original source 
of the expression is as indicated. 
B.1. Oxygen diffusion to/from the atmosphere 
Diffusion of oxygen to or from the water sur- 
face and the overlying atmosphere depends upon 
the difference between the saturation concentra- 
tion of oxygen in the pond water and the actual 
dissolved oxygen concentration present in the 
surface water layer. The mass rate of oxygen 
transfer has been shown to be a function of an 
oxygen transfer coefficient (Tchobanoglous and 
Schroeder, 1985) as: 
MO2D = K ( C s - C) * 1000.1/Tve (B1)

B.2. Fish respiration 
MO2f = Fr* F u (B2) 
(Losordo, 1988), where: 
Fr = (10 (x)) * 1000 (B2.1) 
(Boyd, 1990), where: 
x = - 0.999 - 9.57 * 10 - 4. wt + 6.0 * 10 - 7. (wt) 2 
+ 3.27.10 -2 * Two - 8.7.10 -6 * (Twc) 2

Fr = respiration rate per weight of fish (mg
