F b = FW/(A * d) (B2.2) 
where: F b = average fish biomass concentration 
(kg/m3); FW = total fish biomass (kg); A = pond 
surface area (m2); d = depth (m). 
Inputs of fish biomass are based on periodic 
sampling conducted at the PD/A CRSP research 
sites. In addition, average weights of fish are 
classified into three groups, and the decimal frac- 
tion of these groups (termed 'small,' 'medium,' 
and 'large') is estimated by field personnel (al- 
though for the simulations presented here all of 
the fish were of approximately uniform size, and 
were all lumped into the small category). Respi- 
ration rates are calculated independently for each 
of the fish size classes, and the total fish respira- 
tion term is arrived at by summing the three size 
class terms (Losordo, 1988). 
In order to account for the fact that fish will 
avoid areas of low dissolved oxygen in ponds 
(Gebhart and Summerfelt, 1976) the present 
model also retains the Losordo (1988) method of 
simulating vertical migration by the fish away 
from volume elements which have low D.O. con- 
centrations. At each time step the calculated dis- 
solved oxygen concentration is compared with an 
input term "LOWDO", beginning with the bot- 
tom volume element. If the calculated D.O. con- 
centration is below LOWDO, the model shifts 
the biomass of the fish in the bottom element to 
the middle volume element. The same procedure 
is then repeated for the middle volume element. 
In the event that the calculated dissolved oxygen 
concentration in all three volume elements is 
below LOWDO, all of the fish biomass is consid- 
ered to reside in the surface volume element. 
B.3. Oxygen diffusion within the water column 
Effective diffusion of oxygen in the present 
model is assumed to follow that of energy diffu- 
sion described for the temperature model. While 
there might be other ways in which to conceptual- 
ize and define the effective diffusion of oxygen 
within the pond water volume, the successful use 
of this assumption by Losordo (1988) recom- 
mended identical treatment of oxygen diffusion 
in the present model. The calculation of the 
diffusion of oxygen between water volume ele- 
ments is therefore: 
MO2d,z = Ez, z * (DO 1 - DO2) 
/( zc2 - zcx) * 1000 * 1/th (B3)

Bene�cial bacteria in the pond convert ammonia to nitrite – a less harmful compound utilised by plants. Regularly testing for
ammonia and nitrate levels is essential to monitor the nitrogen cycle’s e�ectiveness.
pH Levels and Hardness
pH levels in your pond water represent the density potential of hydrogen, indicating how acidic or alkaline the water is on a
scale of 0 to 14. A pH level below 7 is acidic, whilst levels above 7 are alkaline; 7 is neutral. 
Water hardness is a measure of the concentration of minerals, mainly calcium and magnesium; it a�ects the bu�ering capacity
(KH or carbonate hardness) of the water. This includes general hardness (GH), which a�ects the health of the �sh and plants in
your pond. 
Carbonate hardness levels need to be high, as this is crucial for the nitrogen cycle. It helps to convert the ammonia and nitrite to
nitrate. What’s more, without the calcium carbonate, there would be no biological �ltration for aquatic life. 
You can improve the KH by adding baking soda (1 cup per 1000 gallons) and adding rocks to your pond. To keep it all in balance,
you should use a pond water test kit that provides accurate pH, KH, and GH readings.
Dissolved Oxygen and Gaseous Exchange
Dissolved oxygen is crucial for all aquatic life and is introduced into the pond through aeration. This can be naturally through
photosynthesis by plants and algae or mechanically by waterfalls or tools designed to aerate the pond.
Monitoring oxygen levels ensures that your �sh have enough oxygen, particularly during the night when photosynthesis isn’t
occurring. Good aeration also promotes bene�cial bacteria activity, which is essential for a healthy nitrogen cycle.
Phosphates
Another factor to look out for in ponds is the presence of phosphates. These are usually only found in established ponds.
Phosphates come from tap water (treatment facilities use them to reduce the concentration of heavy metals), uneaten �sh
food, and broken down plant matter.
They can become harmful, especially for aquatic life, as they slow down the �sh’s ability to take in oxygen. This makes it pivotal
to keep an eye on phosphates, and to use a good �ltration system, which you clean regularly.
Biological and Chemical Factors
In addition to the nitrogen cycle and the presence of bene�cial bacteria, chemical factors also play a signi�cant role in pond
water quality. These include the presence of chemicals from water treatments, which might contain chlorine harmful to �sh and
bacteria.
It is vital to regularly check for these substances and to use appropriate water treatments that do not upset the balance of your
pond ecosystem. Treatments should never impair ammonia, nitrite, or nitrate levels, as these are integral to the ecosystem’s
balance.
Maintaining a balance of these elements is the key to a robust and healthy pond. Regular testing and careful management help
prevent water quality problems that can lead to unhealthy or unsafe conditions for the pond inhabitants.
Testing Procedures and Pond Test Kits
To secure the health of your pond and its inhabitants, it’s essential to conduct regular and precise water tests. By using the right
test kits and understanding how to use them e�ectively, you can sustain optimal water conditions.

__data__.text:
Pond Ecosystem: Discover What It Is & Why It’s
Important
Dive into the world of pond ecosystems, where life thrives in harmonious balance. A pond is not just a quiet pool of water; it’s a
busy place where pond plants, animals, and tiny creatures live together, each helping to keep the place alive and healthy.
In this blog post, we’re going to take a closer look at what happens in a pond ecosystem, and why they are so important.
Join us as we explore the secrets of pond ecosystems, discovering how they work and why they matter.
Key Takeaways
Ponds are self-contained ecosystems bustling with diverse life, including large pond species and small pond species.
Each zone within a pond, from the pond surface to the bottom of the pond, has distinct inhabitants and functions.
Environmental threats require active measures to preserve pond ecosystems, including seasonal ponds and those in areas of shallow water.
Fundamental Components of a Pond Ecosystem
In simpler terms, a pond ecosystem is a dynamic and intricate system, operating as a small-scale freshwater ecosystem that is
both distinct and interlinked with larger aquatic systems.

__data__.text:
What is a Pond Ecosystem?
A pond ecosystem is a dynamic, self-contained freshwater environment where a variety of organisms including plants, animals,
and microorganisms interact and depend on each other for survival. This ecosystem is typically divided into biotic factors
categorised as producers, consumers, and decomposers.
Producers, like aquatic plants and algae, generate energy through photosynthesis, providing oxygen and sustenance to the
ecosystem. Consumers are divided into primary (e.g., zooplankton), secondary (e.g., small �sh), and tertiary (e.g., large �sh and
amphibians), each playing a role in the food chain.
Decomposers, such as bacteria and fungi, break down dead organic material, recycling nutrients back into the ecosystem.
These interactions ensure the balance and health of the pond ecosystem.
Living Components and Their Roles
At the base of the pond’s food web are microorganisms and aquatic plants. These organisms are primary producers, using
sunlight to create energy through photosynthesis.
They are crucial as they produce oxygen and provide food for other pond inhabitants, while shoreline plants absorb nitrogen and
other excess nutrients.
Primary consumers: Small microorganisms and certain animals, like zooplankton, feed on algae and plant material. They are the primary
consumers, supporting higher trophic levels.
Secondary consumers: These include pond invertebrates and some �sh species that consume primary consumers.
Tertiary consumers: Larger �sh species and amphibians represent tertiary consumers, preying on secondary consumers.
Decomposers: Bene�cial bacteria and fungi break down dead organisms and waste products, recycling nutrients back into the pond
ecosystem.
Non-Living Environmental Factors
The non-living, or abiotic factors, shape the ecosystem and include:
Water quality: A range of factors such as temperature, oxygen levels, and the presence of nutrients like nitrogen and phosphates. It’s
important to regularly test pond water to monitor these parameters.
Light: Penetration a�ects photosynthesis rates and in�uences the types of plants and algae that can survive.
Temperature: Determines the metabolic rates of organisms and the capacity of water to hold oxygen.
Nutrients: Availability of nitrogen, phosphorus, and other nutrients mediates the growth of biotic components.
Carbon dioxide: Utilised by plants and algae for photosynthesis, in�uencing the ecosystem’s primary productivity.

__data__.text:
Interactions Within the Pond Ecosystem
In your exploration of a pond ecosystem, you’ll uncover the complex web of relationships between diverse organisms.
Here, energy �ows from the sun to various life forms, and every creature, from the smallest algae to the largest �sh, plays a role
in this aquatic theatre.
Food Chains and Energy Flow
The sun is the ultimate source of energy for ponds. Aquatic plants and algae harness sunlight through photosynthesis, creating
energy-rich compounds.
Zooplankton then graze on these producers, transferring energy up the chain. Small pond species and invertebrates like snails
feed on zooplankton, and in turn, are preyed upon by larger vertebrates such as frogs and bigger �sh.
This sequence forms a pond ecosystem food chain, circulating energy throughout the pond.
Symbioses and Predatory Dynamics
Within this aquatic environment, you’ll �nd fascinating symbiotic relationships. For instance, tadpoles often forage on algae-
covered surfaces, inadvertently providing a cleaning service that bene�ts both parties.
Meanwhile, predatory dynamics are equally important. Predators, including �sh and frogs, keep populations of herbivores like
snails and tadpoles in check, preventing overgrazing and allowing a diverse range of species to thrive.
Carnivores, such as larger �sh, ensure that the energy continues to transfer up the chain, maintaining the balance of the
ecosystem.

Unique Habitats Within Pond Ecosystems
Pond ecosystems host diverse microhabitats that support various forms of life. Understanding these unique zones can enhance
your appreciation of the intricacies within these lentic ecosystems.
Marginal Zones and Plant Life
The marginal zones, often called the littoral zone, are where you �nd a plethora of plant life. These areas are typically shallow and
encompass the pond margin, making them ideal for plant species that thrive in water or at the water’s edge.
Here, you can �nd a range of �oating plants which provide cover and breeding grounds for wildlife like ducks and king�shers.
Submerged plants also create oxygen-rich habitats that are crucial for aquatic organisms.

Cattails
Water Lilies
Irises 
Horsetail
Open-Water and Floor Regions
Venture out into the open-water or limnetic zone, the area often teeming with life that includes small �sh and drifting plants.
The further down you go, the cooler and denser the water becomes; this is known as strati�cation. It’s where light penetration
diminishes, de�ning the transition to the profundal zone at the pond bottom.
Although less hospitable, this zone plays a signi�cant role in the pond ecosystem, serving as the site for nutrient recycling and
home to hardy species adapted to its dark conditions.
Notable wildlife relying on these regions:
Frogs and tadpoles
Insects and their larvae
Benthic organisms

Challenges and Sustainability
Ponds are subject to various challenges that can impact their sustainability. Pollution can introduce excess nutrients, leading to
algal blooms that deplete oxygen and harm pond species.
Seasonal ponds may dry up, a�ecting small animals and microscopic animals dependent on these habitats. Addressing these
issues is vital for preserving the delicate equilibrium of a pond’s ecosystem.
Environmental Stressors and Biodiversity
Ponds, as microcosms of freshwater habitats, harbour rich biodiversity but are often subject to environmental stressors that
threaten their ecological balance.
Pollutants can lead to algal blooms, which deplete oxygen and can cause �sh kills in your �sh ponds. A key challenge is
preserving the varied forms of life that ponds support, including some endangered species that rely on this habitat for survival.
Conservation and Management Strategies
To tackle these challenges, conservation and management strategies must be robust and research-led. The goal for wildlife
ponds and freshwater ponds is to sustain ecosystem services and maintain a thriving biodiversity.
Actions such as regulating pollutants, creating bu�ers around ponds to protect them from run-o� and implementing
sustainable land management practices are vital.
Engagement with these strategies can make progress in conserving these precious ecosystems a reality, as seen in initiatives
focusing on sustainability indices.
What Can Help Maintain A Balanced Ecosystem?
Plants: With algae being a type of plant, allowing other plants into the pond means that the algae starve nutrients in the water. There is a
large array of aquatic plants available, which will help balance the ecosystem and look beautiful in and around your garden pond.
Fish: Fish can LOVE algae. Koi �sh can feed on algae if they are large enough, slowly and gradually reducing algae growth.
Filtration Systems: Filtration allows for circulating oxygen and the removal of any debris, including �sh waste. Skimmers are fantastic for a

__data__.text:
Transform Your Garden: Create a Thriving Pond Ecosystem with Our
Expertise
Are you inspired to create your own pond ecosystem or revitalise an existing one? Whether you’re dreaming of a tranquil garden
retreat with a beautiful koi pond or a functional wildlife pond supporting local wildlife, the team at Ponds by Michael Wheat is
here to help bring your vision to life.
With expertise in crafting bespoke pond designs that harmonise with your garden’s aesthetic while promoting ecological
balance, our specialists are dedicated to creating spaces and pond maintenance packages that not only enhance your outdoor
environment but also contribute positively to the local ecosystem.
Contact us to start your pond project and take a step towards a more sustainable and biodiverse garden.
10 Interesting Pond Ecosystem Facts
1. Diverse Inhabitants: Did you know a single pond can house over 1,000 di�erent species? From the tiniest microorganisms to vibrant �sh
and amphibians, ponds are bustling cities of nature. Each creature plays a crucial role, contributing to the delicate balance of the
ecosystem.
2. Natural Water Filters: Ponds act as Earth’s kidneys, �ltering some pollutants and sediments from water through a process involving
aquatic plants, bacteria, and soil. This natural �ltration ensures cleaner, healthier environments for both aquatic life and the surrounding
community.
3. Biodiversity Hotspots: Ponds are biodiversity hotspots, essential for maintaining genetic diversity among species. This diversity is crucial
for resilience to diseases and changing environmental conditions, ensuring ecosystem health and stability.
4. Educational Platforms: Pond ecosystems provide unique learning opportunities. They allow for close-up observations of food chains,
reproductive cycles, and seasonal changes, making them invaluable educational resources for people of all ages.
5. Wellness and Recreation: The calming presence of a pond contributes to human wellness and recreation. Spending time near water
bodies or in swimming ponds can reduce stress, improve mood, and enhance overall well-being, especially for pond owners.
6. Carbon Sinks: By supporting a variety of plant life, ponds act as carbon sinks , absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This
process is essential for mitigating the e�ects of climate change, highlighting the environmental signi�cance of pond ecosystems.
7. Wildlife Corridors: Ponds act as vital rest stops and resources for migratory birds and other animal species, o�ering shelter, food, and
breeding sites. A healthy ecosystem pond is critical for supporting wildlife populations and maintaining biodiversity.
8. Indicator of Environmental Health: The health of a pond ecosystem often re�ects the health of its surrounding environment. A thriving
pond suggests a healthy, balanced ecosystem, while issues like algal blooms can indicate pollution or ecological imbalance.
9. Supports Pollinators: Ponds attract a myriad of pollinators including bees, butter�ies, and birds, providing them with water and habitat.
This supports not only the local biodiversity but also the health of surrounding gardens and crops.

metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf

__data__.text:
Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in
pond ecosystems
Hideyuki Doi, Kwang-Hyeon Chang, Takamitsu Ando, Ippei Ninomiya, Hiroyuki Imai
and Shin-ichi Nakano
H. Doi (h-doi@agr.ehime-u.ac.jp), T. Ando, I. Ninomiya, H. Imai and S. Nakano, LAFWEDY, Faculty of Agriculture, Ehime Univ., 3-5-7,
Tarumi, Matsuyama, JP /C1790-8566, Ehime, Japan. /C1K.-H. Chang, Center for Marine Environmental Studies (CMES), Ehime Univ.,
Bunkyo-cho 2-5, JP /C1790-8577 Matsuyama, Japan.
Food-chain length (FCL) in ecosystems has been studied extensively, and numerous hypotheses to predict FCL,
productivity, ecosystem size, and productive space have been proposed. For example, the productivity hypothesis suggests
that resource availability limits FCL, whereas the productive-space hypothesis predicts that per-unit-size resource
availability and ecosystem size equally limit FCL. However, previous studies have only measured total productivity to test
FCL and have never tested the impact of resource availability within a system on FCL. Therefore, we estimated FCL in
15 ponds using stable isotope techniques to test the most common hypotheses for predicting FCL. We also measured
total productivity, pond volume (ecosystem size), and edible microalgal carbon (resource availability) in each pond. We
found that productive-space (edible carbon /C27pond volume) was the best model to predict FCL, and FCL was
significantly correlated with edible carbon and pond volume. However, factors such as total productivity did not directly
predict FCL of the ponds. Therefore, our results suggest that both resource availability and ecosystem size predict FCL in
pond ecosystems and play significant roles in maintaining longer FCLs. Furthermore, the productive-space hypothesis
appears to be particularly important for determining the FCL of ponds.
Food webs depict the complex trophic interactions among
organisms within ecosystems. Food chain length (FCL),
which is a measure of the number of trophic levels in a
system between primary producers and the top predator, is
commonly used to estimate the characteristics of food webs
in an ecosystem. FCL has been recognized as a central
ecosystem characteristic and a fundamental ecosystem
attribute (Elton 1927, Pimm 1982). Previous studies have
shown that FCL varies greatly among systems (Elton 1927,
Pimm 1982, Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al. 2000,
Thompson and Townsend 2005, Vander Zanden and
Fetzer 2007).
Defining the factors that determine FCL has been a
primary research focus for food web ecologists. Numerous
widely cited hypotheses have been proposed, such as the
dynamic stability hypothesis, which argues that the stability
of local dynamics (Pimm and Lawton 1977, Jenkins et al.
1992) and the level of disturbance (Power et al. 1996)
contribute to FCL. However, three main hypotheses
(Fig. 1) have been examined in previous reports (Vander
Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al. 2000, Thompson and
Townsend 2005, Post 2007, Vander Zanden and Fetzer
2007). The productivity hypothesis predicts that energy
availability limits FCL (Elton 1927, Pimm 1982), whereas
the ecosystem size hypothesis predicts that FCL increases
with increasing ecosystem size (e.g. lake volume; Cohen and
Newman 1992). A study by Post et al. (2000) that
examined FCL in temperate lakes strongly supported the
ecosystem size hypothesis. Finally, the productive-space
hypothesis is a combination of the productivity and the
ecosystem size hypotheses. It argues that total ecosystem
production (per-unit-size productivity /C29ecosystem size)
reflects the capacity of an ecosystem to support additional
trophic levels (Schoener 1989). For example, if maximum
FCL is limited by energy transfer inefficiencies, then
predators will have to forage over a wider area to meet
energy requirements in low energy habitats (Pimm 1982).
Unlike previous energetic hypotheses that are based on
estimates of per-unit-size resource availability (i.e. the
productivity hypothesis), the productive-space hypothesis
explicitly includes a spatial component to accurately
estimate the total availability of resources for upper trophic
levels. This hypothesis postulates that per-unit-size resource
availability and ecosystem size should have equal effects on
FCL (Schoener 1989, Fig. 1).
Post (2002a) reported that ecosystem size is an im-
portant factor in determining FCL in lake ecosystems and
that resource availability has little effect in determining
food-chain length in natural systems. On the other hand,
some studies have supported the productivity hypothesis
Oikos 118: 138 /C1144, 2009
doi: 10.1111/j.1600-0706.2008.17171.x,
# 2008 The Authors. Journal compilation # 2008 Oikos
Subject Editor: Jeremy Fox. Accepted 22 July 2008
138

metadata.file_name: Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf
metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf

__data__.text:
(Yodzis 1984, Jenkins et al. 1992, Kaunzinger and Morin
1998, Thompson and Townsend 2005). For example,
Thompson and Townsend (2005) showed that the carbon
productivity of benthic algae predicted the FCL of streams.
Originally, the productivity and productive-space hy-
potheses predicted that resource availability limited FCL. It
is well-accepted that energy availability plays an important
role in ecological systems. Indeed, Lawton (1999) suggested
that this is one of the general patterns in ecology. However,
previous studies that examine FCL have focused on total
productivity (e.g. carbon production rate, total phosphorus,
and Secchi transparency), and the impact of resource
availability on FCL remains largely unexamined.
We focused on the ability of resource availability to
predict FCL. We estimated resource availability as the
amount of edible carbon in a given system, which was
calculated by estimating the edibility of algal communities,
and has been shown to clearly impact ecosystem functions
and species diversity (Agrawal 1998, Hall et al. 2006). In
lakes with high productivity, inedible algae often dominate
(Watson and McCauley 1988, Watson et al. 1992). Such a
paradox would make it difficult to test the productivity and
productive-space hypothesis using the total productivity in
lake ecosystems.
Studies that examine FCL often use stable isotopes and
gut content analyses (Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al .
2000, Thompson and Townsend 2005, Vander Zanden
and Fetzer 2007). Carbon isotopes provide an indication of
the food sources of consumers (Peterson and Fry 1987,
McCutchan et al. 2003), and nitrogen isotopes reflect the
trophic position of consumers (Vander Zanden and
Rasmussen 2001, Post 2002b). Previous FCL studies that
used stable isotopes defined the trophic position of a top
predator in an ecosystem as the FCL of that system (Vander
Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al. 2000, Vander Zanden and
Fetzer 2007).
We investigated the FCL in 15 pond ecosystems using
stable isotope techniques. We also examined the total
productivity and pond volume (ecosystem size) as in
previous studies, as well as edible carbon as a measure of
resource availability in each pond.
Material and methods
Study sites
The study was conducted in 15 ponds located within 33848?/C1
50?N and 132 848?/C155?E in Matsuyama, Japan. Some of
ponds in this area were excluded from the sampling due to
the absence of largemouth bassMicropterus salmoides, the top
predator fish. The 15 ponds experienced an invasion of
largemouth bass, which was introduced in the 1970/C11980s
and subsequently became the top predator of these systems.
We did not include the other piscivorous fish in the ponds in
our observations. The zooplanktivorous fishes were mainly
bluegill and small crucian (H. Ohnishi et al. pers. comm.,
Doi unpubl.). We conducted all field surveys and samplings
one to three times from October to November 2005.
Figure 1. Predicted relationship between food-chain length
(FCL), resource availability, and ecosystem size (log-transformed
values) by three mainstream hypotheses to determine FCL. For the
productive-space hypothesis, total ecosystem production, log
(resource availability /C29ecosystem size) is equal to (log resource
availability)/C27(log ecosystem size).
139

metadata.file_name: Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf
metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf

__data__.text:
Collection and measurement of isotope samples
Zooplankton were collected by vertical net towing (200 mm
mesh net) from near the bottom to the surface of each
pond. For the stable isotope analysis, zooplankton samples
were kept cool without preservation during transportation
to the laboratory. Chironomid larvae (mainly Chironomi-
dae) and snails were collected from the littoral zone of each
pond by hand and a hand net. Largemouth bass were
collected by angling and netting from the pelagic zones of
the ponds. We measured the standard length (to the nearest
0.5 cm) of bass, and the muscle tissues of bass and the
whole body tissues of invertebrates were used for isotope
analysis. All samples were dried at 608C for at least 24 h and
stored in desiccators until the isotope ratios were analyzed.
Carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios of the samples were
measured with a continuous flow isotope mass spectro-
meter. All isotopic data are reported in the conventionald
notation where d13Co r d15N/C30(Rsample/Rstandard /C11)/C29
1000 ( /C152), where R is the 13C/12Co r 15N/14N ratio for
d13Co r d15N, respectively. Pee Dee Belemnite and N 2 in
air were used as international standards for d13C and d15N,
respectively. The overall analytical errors were within 9
0.2/C152for both d13C and d15N.
Measurements of ecological conditions
We used the edibility of the algal community as a direct
measure of resource availability in each pond. Nutrient
concentrations (especially total phosphorus), chlorophyll a ,
and Secchi transparency were used as productivity indices in
each pond. Ecosystem size was measured by estimating total
pond volume as a hyperbolic sinusoid: 0.43 /C29surface
area/C29maximum depth (Post et al. 2000).
To determine phytoplankton compositions, chlorophyll
a concentration, and nutrient concentrations of surface
water, we collected 2 l of surface water (0 /C150 cm depth)
with a column sampler, and 250-ml portions of the water
sample were fixed with acidified Lugol’s solution to a final
concentration of 1% for enumeration of phytoplankton.
The phytoplankton sample was poured into a tapered glass
tube with a pre-determined volume and was concentrated
by natural sedimentation. The phytoplankton species were
counted in a Burker /C1Turk type hematocytometer under a
microscope. We split algal samples into edible ( B40 mm)
and inedible ( /C2140 mm) size fractions (Cottingham 1999,
Hall et al. 2006). Microcystis (blue-green algae) and
Aulacoseira (filamentous diatoms) were the dominant
inedible algae in the study ponds. We estimated edible
Figure 2. Correlation plots of the factors explaining food-chain lengths of the ponds. Factors include edible carbon (resource availability),
total phosphorus (TP), chlorophyll a concentration, Secchi depth /C281 (productivity), and pond volume (ecosystem size).
140

__data__.text:
carbon using a cell volume to carbon equation (volume
calculations were microscopically measured; Rocha and
Duncan 1985, Hillebrand et al. 1999).
Each 250 ml aliquot of water sample was filtered
through a 0.2 mm Nuclepore filter to retain seston. The
filter was placed in a glass test tube, and N,N-dimethylfor-
mamide was added to extract the chlorophyll a. Chlorophyll
a concentration was determined using a fluorometer
(Moran and Porath 1980). Nutrient concentrations in the
surface water (NO 2
/C28/C27NO3
/C28,N H 4
/C27, Si, and total phos-
phorus, TP) were determined by colorimetric analysis with
a continuous flow system. We also measured Secchi depth
at the center of ponds and estimated the Secchi transpar-
ency by inversed Secchi depth. While we did not directly
measure primary productivity, the productivity indices used
in this study have been used in previous tests of the three
FCL hypotheses in lakes (Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post
et al. 2000). We used three productivity indices (chlor-
ophyll a concentration, TP, and Secchi depth) to ensure
that an accurate and representative measure of productivity
was included in our analyses.
Data analyses
To estimate the FCL of each pond, we used the isotope data
of largemouth bass, chironomid larvae (mainly Chirono-
midae), and the zooplankton (mainlyDaphnia and Bos-
mina) as top-predator, benthic, and pelagic isotope
baselines, respectively. We used averaged data of the species
collected throughout the sampling period. Although some
previous studies used snails and mussels as benthic and
pelagic isotope baselines (Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post
et al. 2000), we did not find snails and mussels in many of
the study ponds. However, we found that thed15No f
zooplankton and mussels ( Anadonata woodiana ) did not
differ significantly between two of the ponds (t-test, p /C30
0.28), and the d15N of chironomid larvae and snails
(Lymnaeidae) were not significantly different in four ponds
(t-test, p /C300.39). We estimated the FCL of each pond
using nitrogen and carbon isotopes as follows (Vander
Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al. 2000):
FCL/C302/C27(d15Nbass
/C28[d15Nchi /C29a/C27d15NZoo /C29(1/C28a)])=3:4
a/C30(d13Cbass /C28d13Czoo)=(d13Cchi /C28d13Czoo)
where bass, chi, and zoo represent largemouth bass as the
top predator, chironomid larvae as the benthic isotope
baseline, and zooplankton as the pelagic isotope baseline,
respectively. We assumed a trophic fractionation value of
3.4/C152to calculate FCL in the same manner as in previous
studies (Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al. 2000,
Vander Zanden and Fetzer 2007).
Post (2007) discussed methods for testing the produc-
tive-space hypothesis using a field dataset. The productive-
space hypothesis originally predicted that per-unit resource
availability and ecosystem size equally limited FCL. How-
ever, both resource availability and ecosystem size alone
strongly affected his results. He therefore suggested that the
dual gradient (resource availability and ecosystem size)
approach is better than a single gradient (calculated
productive-space, resource availability /C29ecosystem size) to

metadata.file_name: Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf
metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf

__data__.text:
test the productive-space hypothesis. Thus, we tested the
productive-space hypothesis using a general linear model
(GLM) with both resource availability (log edible carbon)
and ecosystem size (log pond volume) separately.
In addition, we tested a single linear model with log
edible carbon and log pond volume. We calculated the
R2 values of the models and tested whether the results fit the
three models using an F-test. We also performed GLMs
with edible carbon, pond volume, chlorophyll, TP, and
Secchi depth/C281as independent variables explaining FCL
and selected the best model using the stepwise method with
Akaike’s information criterion (AIC). We estimated the
correlation among these same factors and FCL using
Pearson’s correlation coefficients (a/C300.05). Factors were
log10-transformed, and Secchi depth /C281 was transformed by
log10(x/C271). We performed the statistical analyses using R
ver. 2.6.2 software (R Development Core Team 2008).
Results
Relationships among variables
We found no significant correlations among factors,
including edible carbon, TP, chlorophyll a, and Secchi
transparency, and pond volume (p/C210.2, Table 1, Fig. 2).
Thus, total productivity and resource availability (edible
carbon) were not remarkably influenced by other factors,
and resource availability and ecosystem size (pond volume)
were not correlated. Other nutrients (NO 2/C27NO3 and Si)
also did not influence the FCL of the ponds (r B0.2,
pB0.2, Table 1). Finally, there was no correlation between
the standard lengths of the largemouth bass (17 /C132 cm)
collected from the pelagic zones of the ponds and FCL
(r/C30/C280.36, p/C210.2).
Resource availability and ecosystem size on FCL
Benthic (‘a’ in the FCL equation) and planktonic contribu-
tions (1 /C1a) to FCL were 0.73 90.05 and 0.27 90.05
(mean91 SE, n /C3015), respectively. Thus, the FCL of the
ponds can be considered to depend largely on the
planktonic food chain. The correlation between FCL and
edible carbon (i.e. resource availability) was significantly
positive (r/C300.58, p B0.05), as was that between FCL and
pond volume (i.e. ecosystem size; r /C300.57, p B0.05; Fig.
3). Productivity factors including TP, chlorophyll a , and
Secchi transparency were not significantly correlated with
FCL ( jrj B0.39, p /C210.1). The GLM including edible
carbon and pond volume was selected as the best model
(AIC/C3010.6) among the GLMs with explanatory factors
(AIC of full model /C3014.6). Thus, TP, chlorophyll a , and
Secchi transparency did not significantly predict FCL.
We also evaluated resource availability and ecosystem
size separately. The F-test results indicated that the model
that incorporated the log volume and log edible carbon
(R2 /C300.58) was significantly better than the model in-
corporating single regression with log volume and log edible
carbon (F /C304.79 and 4.58, respectively, p B0.05).
Discussion
Our results indicated that both resource availability and
ecosystem size can predict FCL in pond ecosystems, thus
supporting the productive-space hypothesis. This hypoth-
esis combines the productivity and ecosystem size hypoth-
eses and predicts that maximum FCL can be predicted by
the amount of productive space (resource availability /C29
ecosystem size; Schoener 1989). Post et al. (2000) rejected
the productivity and productive-space hypotheses using a
dataset of FCL in lakes, and Post (2002a) suggested that
resource availability contributes little to determining FCL
in most natural systems. However, these conclusions were
the result of limited among-lake variation in productivity
(1/C12 orders of magnitude) and large variation in lake
Figure 3. Correlation plots between food-chain length (FCL) and the factors in each pond. Factors include edible carbon (resource
availability), total phosphorus (TP), chlorophyll a concentration, Secchi depth/C281 (productivity), and pond volume (ecosystem size). FCL
is signiﬁcantly positively correlated with edible carbon and pond volume (r /C300.57 and 0.58, respectively, p B0.01).
Figure 4. Three-dimensional plots between food-chain length
(FCL), resource availability (edible carbon), and ecosystem size
(pond volume) in each pond. The dot plane indicates a linear
model for FCL; FCL /C300.20/C29log edible carbon /C270.32/C29log
pond volume/C272.42.
142

metadata.file_name: Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf
metadata.file_path: C:\gdrive\algorithms\deltares\vfn-chat\examples\pond\data\ecosystem\Resource availability and ecosystem size predict food-chain length in pond ecosystems.pdf

__data__.text:
volume (/C27 orders of magnitude). Vander Zanden et al.
(1999) also tested the productive-space hypothesis using a
dataset of FCL in lakes; however, in their study, total
ecosystem production and lake area (i.e. ecosystem size)
were strongly correlated. The logical extension of this
relationship is that ecosystem size is a measure of ecosystem
production, which highlights the inherent difficulty in
separating the effects of these variables (Vander Zanden
and Fetzer 2007). However, in our study, resource avail-
ability played a significant role in predicting FCL, although
we did not find a significant relationship between our
productivity index and FCL. Furthermore, among-lake
variation in edible carbon and ecosystem size was of similar
order of magnitude (2 /C13 orders of magnitude, Fig. 4), and
neither was significantly correlated with each other. There-
fore, our results from pond ecosystems support the
productive-space hypothesis for predicting FCL.
The ecosystem size hypothesis incorporates a variety of
factors, including patterns of community assembly and the
effects of ecosystem size on habitat heterogeneity, species
richness, and the scale of local interactions (Post et al. 2000,
Post 2002a). This hypothesis does not imply that resource
availability is unimportant; however, Schoener (1989)
argued that larger systems contain more total available
energy as a result of their size. Such a system would support
more individuals per species, and consequently, individual
species would be more likely to persist. Increasing resource
availability also increases the total production of a system.
Schoener (1989) also reported that the productive-space
hypothesis predicted the response of individuals within food
webs. In a resource-limited situation, the volume required
to support a single individual of a particular species depends
on the resource availability of that volume. Our results
indicate that when resource availability (edible algal carbon)
is limited in the ponds, the pond volume needed to support
an individual increases. In the study lakes of Winter (1977),
the maximum home range size of largemouth bass ranged
from 0.3 to 1.4/C29104 m2, and the primary or used ranges
were approximately 0.4 /C29104 m2. Our data suggest that in
our study ponds (10 3/C1105 m2), the habitat area of large-
mouth bass may be limited, and as a result, the total
resource availability of systems could predict the FCL of
ponds with largemouth bass. We also found that the FCLs
for the particular volumes of our study ponds (103/C1105 m3)
were shorter than in the lakes (10 5/C11013 m3) examined in
previous studies (Vander Zanden et al. 1999, Post et al.
2000). Thus, the total resource availability of a system plays
a direct role in the prediction of FCL in small ponds.
We used edible carbon as a measure of resource
availability in pond ecosystems to test three well known
hypotheses for predicting FCL. Our results indicated that
both resource availability and ecosystem size can predict FCL
in pond ecosystems. When space is limited, the productive-
space hypothesis plays a significant role in determining FCL.
Future studies should consider the index of resource
availability for testing the productive-space hypothesis.
Acknowledgements /C1We sincerely thank J. M. Vander Zanden for
his helpful comments on an earlier manuscript. We are grateful to
J. W. Fox for valuable comments on the manuscript. We thank A.
Kajimoto, T. Yamamoto, W. Izumi and N. Nishihara for ﬁeld
sampling and sample preparations. This study was supported by a

__data__.text:
Advanced Review
The ecology and biodiversity
of urban ponds
Christopher Hassall∗
Recent research has demonstrated that ponds contribute a great deal to biodiversity
at a regional level as networks of habitat patches that also act as ‘stepping stones’
to facilitate the movement of species through the landscape. Similarly, a great deal
of biodiversity persists in urban environments where synanthropic communities
are supplemented by species that thrive in disturbed environments. Aquatic
urban biodiversity appears to persist despite anthropogenic stressors: an array of
anthropogenic pollutants (road salt and heavy metals), invasive species, and active
mismanagement—particularly the removal of riparian vegetation. Optimizing
urban ponds for different ecosystem services results in conﬂicting priorities
over hydrological, geochemical, ecological, aesthetic, and cultural functions.
The socio-ecosystem approach to environmental management opens a path
to greater incorporation of biodiversity into town planning and sustainability,
while accounting for cultural attitudes to urban ecosystems. I identify a range of
research needs: (1) the roles of design and location of urban ponds in inﬂuencing
biodiversity, (2) the function of urban wetlands for stormwater and pollution
management, and (3) public perceptions of urban ecosystems and how those
perceptions are inﬂuenced by interactions with natural systems. Urban wetlands
offer an important opportunity to educate the general public on natural systems
and science in general using a resource that is located on their doorstep. In
the face of increasing pressures on natural systems and increasing extent and
intensity of urbanization, a more comprehensive appreciation of the challenges
and opportunities provided by urban ponds could play a substantial role in driving
sustainable urban development. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
How to cite this article:
WIREs Water2014, 1:187–206. doi: 10.1002/wat2.1014
INTRODUCTION
L
and-use change, whether a conversion from
natural habitat to agricultural or urban land,
is likely to be the principle driver of biodiversity
declines over the next century in all biomes.1 Current
projections of urban land use suggest that between
2000 and 2030 there will be at least a 185%
increase in the extent of urban areas2 (Figure 1),
posing a serious threat to biodiversity around the
world, and much of this threat is concentrated
in high biodiversity areas in developing countries.3
However, concomitant plans for urban intensiﬁcation
∗Correspondence to: c.hassall@leeds.ac.uk
School of Biology, University of Leeds, Leeds, UK
Conﬂict of interest: The author has declared no conﬂicts of interest
for this article.
in developed countries bring a parallel set of
problems through a reduction in remaining habitat
patches through processes such as inﬁll housing. 4,5
When attempting to mitigate the environmental
consequences of this rapid expansion of towns and
cities, it is important that the creation of these urban
areas not be thought of simply as the removal of
natural habitat. The processes that drive urbanization
involve complex, interacting sets of physical,
social, economic, and governmental institutions
with complex sets of interacting stakeholders.6
With increasing demands being placed upon the
natural world, it is important to consider this
range of institutions when attempting to safeguard
biodiversity in the long term. Furthermore, regional
variations in sociopolitical priorities necessitate local
approaches to the management of this problem.
Volume 1, March/April 2014 © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. 187

__data__.text:
Advanced Review wires.wiley.com/water
FIGURE 1 | Past trends and future projections of urbanization (%
population living in urban areas) by continent. Source: Population
Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United
Nations Secretariat World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision and
World Urbanization Prospects: The 2009 Revision.
http://esa.un.org/wup2009/unup/.
Approaches to the protection of biodiversity in
the face of urbanization require interdisciplinary
collaboration with researchers and practitioners
in a range of other ﬁelds, including urban
planners, economists, and sociologists, to provide
a broader perspective on the ‘socio-ecosystem’. 7,8
Indeed, successful interdisciplinary approaches to the
protection and enhancement of biodiversity under
urbanization could not only offset the negative
impacts on biodiversity but also facilitate a more
rapid transition to sustainability.6
Freshwaters represent a set of habitats that
suffer greater biodiversity declines than terrestrial
habitats,1 perhaps owing to the disproportionate
biodiversity that is found in inland waters. 9 Threats
to these habitats tend to result from ﬁve key
factors: species invasion, habitat degradation, water
pollution, overexploitation, and ﬂow modiﬁcation. 9
The remainder of this article will consider the topic of
urban pond ecology from two opposite angles: after
providing an overview of the ecology of ponds and
the nature of urbanization, I shall ﬁrst discuss the
positive and negative impacts that urbanization has
on pond ecosystems. This will cover topics such as
pollution, habitat connectivity, and neglect, but also
pond creation for amenity. Second, I shall provide
an overview of the contributions made by ponds to
ecosystem services within urban areas. In particular,
I will emphasize the conﬂict between competing
interests in limited urban spaces, but in closing I
will summarize some of the many promising avenues
for the protection, use, and development of this
habitat. The review will focus predominantly on the
literature from northwest Europe, where the majority
of work has been carried out, with notes about future
directions in other regions.
THE VALUE OF URBAN PONDS
Biodiversity
Pond Ecosystems
Before giving closer consideration to ponds in urban
areas, it is useful to understand the nature of small,
lentic water bodies in general. The deﬁnition of
a ‘pond’ is an artiﬁcial one that varies between
researchers. While a wide range of potential deﬁnitions
exist, ponds are generally deﬁned in terms of
their area: being either <2h a10 or <5h a .11 Small
landscape elements such as ponds have traditionally
been considered as providing insigniﬁcant biodiversity
to the regional species pool compared with larger
habitats such as lakes and rivers. 12 However, while
many individual ponds may contain relatively few
species (α-diversity), these habitats constitute an
enormous diversity of abiotic and biotic conditions.
This diversity of environments creates a concomitant
diversity in ecological communities ( β-diversity),
which, in turn, results in a greater contribution to
landscape-level biodiversity (γ-diversity) than those
of larger wetlands that are more homogeneous. 13–15
In addition to this complexity, the small size of
ponds is thought to break down standard species–area
relationship owing to the small island effect.16,17 This
stochasticity means that a pond that holds a high
biodiversity at one time point may not remain of
high ecological value at another, 18 rendering site-
speciﬁc conservation measures ineffective and instead
necessitating the conservation of pond clusters or
networks.19
Ponds have also been overlooked from a
legislative standpoint, being omitted from the
EU Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC) that
dictates standards for water quality. 12 While
monitoring of lakes and rivers occurs in the
EU and worldwide to ensure compliance with
environmental legislation such as the WFD, ponds
are not monitored. Certain standing waters are
protected under EU legislation such as the EU
Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC) Annex I, including
dystrophic lakes/ponds and Mediterranean temporary
ponds, and others can be protected based on ﬂoral
or faunal communities. In some countries, such as
the UK, high-quality ponds have been recognized as
priority habitats, and therefore receive some statutory
protection. However, an absence of monitoring of
188 © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Volume 1, March/April 2014

__data__.text:
WIREs Water Ecology and biodiversity of urban ponds
sites may lead to conservationists failing to recognize
such sites.
Urban Ecosystems
Because the urban environment is tailored to
human needs, urban areas share many features in
common irrespective of geographical proximity20
and are inﬂuenced by the same network of
processes.21 This fact, combined with the unique
socioeconomic and cultural interactions between
urban habitats and human populations has led
to a call for a discrete ﬁeld of ‘urban ecology’
to be founded.22 It is often considered that by
creating such uniform environmental conditions,
urbanization homogenizes biological communities.23
This ‘biotic homogenization’ 24 occurs through
three complementary processes of (1) exclusion of
native species through habitat modiﬁcation, (2)
the introduction of exotic species through human
processes (explored in more detailed below), and
(3) the establishment of exotic species through
habitat disturbance. However, the details of these
processes remain unclear.25 Based on published
ﬂoral inventories for 54 Central European cities,
Pyˇsek26 found that an average of 40% of urban
ﬂoral communities comprised alien species (range:
20–60%). It has been argued that this modiﬁcation
of ﬂoral communities is the only direct biological
modiﬁcation made by humans, and that faunal
responses are determined by this plant ‘template’.27
Similar ratios occur in introduced versus native bird
communities.28 The net result of urbanization is
not always a decline in species richness: studies
comparing varying levels of urbanization show that
while invertebrates and birds exhibit considerable
monotonic declines (though cf. Ref 29 with respect
to birds) with increasing urbanization, plant species
richness peaks at intermediate levels. 30 Furthermore,
trends seems to vary markedly between studies 30
and even between rural–urban transects in the same
region.31
Urban Ponds
In a review of anthropogenic refuges for freshwater
biodiversity, Chester and Robson describe 16 types
of man-made freshwaters of which ‘urban pond’ is a
single category.32 However, urban ponds are a diverse
group of habitats that vary in their characteristics, and
in Table 1 I have proposed a typology of these urban
ponds in terms of their primary function: garden pond,
industrial ponds, ornamental lakes, drainage systems,
and nature reserves. Note that this table is by no
means comprehensive. I have omitted unusual (though
fascinating) systems such as bomb crater ponds, e.g.,
Refs 49 and 50, swimming pools, e.g., Ref 51, and
monumental fountains, e.g., Ref 52, in favor of those
habitats that are more common and better-studied.
Note that while some other ‘unusual’ habitats (such
as stormwater management facilities) are very well
studied, ponds dedicated to the preservation of nature
in urban areas are less well known. This leaves open
the question of whether urban nature reserves either
contain a large number of urban species or represent
a non-urban, ‘natural’ community within an urban
matrix. Further, it is important to note that the
typology is not static: it is not uncommon for water
bodies to change functions, such as the adoption
of industrial ponds by angling clubs. 36 While this
management can reduce diversity, it also reduces the
likelihood of the water body being lost owing to
development or drainage.36,37 Such studies of the fate
of urban wetlands under demographic and economic
transitions are rare, but will become important as
developing countries move away from industrial and
manufacturing economies toward the service industry.
The extent of biodiversity contained within
urban ponds varies markedly in terms of extent
and composition. While a range of studies have
reported (with some surprise) that urban wetlands can
support substantial biodiversity despite being in close
proximity to human habitats, 38,41,53,54 it is unclear
as to whether this is due to the lack of reporting
of poor-quality urban wetlands that are considered
uninteresting. Table 2 gives a summary of studies
that have been conducted involving the measurement
of biodiversity in urban ponds. Biodiversity of certain
groups has received more attention than that of others,
and amphibians have been particularly well studied.
Amphibians appear to follow the general trend of
a decline in diversity and abundance toward the
center of built-up areas, 69 which is likely due to a
combination of low habitat quality (in particular,
ornamental edging made from stone or wood
reduces amphibian diversity owing to amphibians not
being able to climb the vertical surface) and poor
connectivity between habitat patches. 39 However, it
is important to consider species-speciﬁc sensitivity, as
some species appear to be quite resilient to the effects
of urbanization, 70 and so declines in diversity may
represent the loss of particular, disproportionately
affected species rather than a uniform effect on the
entire species pool.
Fish diversity is rarely considered within
urban ponds, apart from in the contexts of (1)
introductions of alien species by residents, 58 or
(2) as a presence/absence of variable inﬂuencing
the composition of macroinvertebrate communities.71
While the low dispersal ability of ﬁsh species through
Volume 1, March/April 2014 © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. 189

__data__.text:
Advanced Review wires.wiley.com/water
TABLE 1 A Proposed Typology of Urban Ponds Based on Primary Function
Urban Pond Type Characteristics Refs
Garden pond • Small size (101 m2)
• Set within an impervious matrix
• Often stocked with ﬁsh
• Very rarely dry out
• Maintained to prevent succession
33–35
Industrial ponds • Medium size (102–104 m2)
• Urban or periurban, often away from residential areas
• Sometimes contaminated
• Constructed to hold water for use, or left after mineral extraction
• Rarely in use for original purpose
36–38
Ornamental lakes and ponds • Medium-large size (102–106 m2)
• Heavily managed for aesthetics
• Hypertrophic
• Fish and ducks encouraged and fed
• Access to public is encouraged and uncontrolled
• Often with vertical sides that may pose problems for animals
39,40
Drainage systems • Highly variable in size (102–106 m2)
• Primary function is hydrological management
• Diverse design
• Wide variation in ‘naturalness’
• Temporary (‘detention basins’) or permanent (‘retention ponds’)
41–48
Nature reserves • Medium-large size (102–106 m2)
• Managed primarily for biodiversity (often birds)
• Either co-opted natural ponds or created to appear natural
• Access to public is encouraged but controlled
terrestrial matrices, particularly in urban areas, likely
reduces the incidence of natural ecological processes
of colonization, extinction, and community assembly,
urban ﬁsh populations require greater study as they
are key drivers of ecosystem functioning. Similarly,
urban aquatic plant communities tend to be viewed as
anthropogenic imports rather than embattled native
communities (more on invasive plants below). One
exception is planktonic communities, which have
received particular attention because of the potential
for nuisance species to become established periodically
in disturbed and temporary wetlands.72,73
Insect biodiversity has also been measured,
although to a lesser extent. Urban ponds in Germany
have been shown to have the potential to contain a
large number of dragonﬂy and damselﬂy (Odonata)
species, although diversity is strongly related to the
presence of vegetation. 40 Urban water bodies can
house a considerable portion of the national species
pool for some invertebrate taxa (e.g., Hirudinea,
Gastropoda, and Tricladida), but more sensitive taxa
(e.g., Plecoptera and Ephemeroptera) tend to be
excluded.53 However, the converse can also be true:
in natural areas that are inﬂuenced by human activity,
certain artiﬁcial water bodies such as reservoirs can
act as refugia for species.41,42,61
A brief consideration of the range of biodiversity
studies reveals two signiﬁcant patterns. The ﬁrst
is that there have been no comprehensive food
web studies looking at urban environments. This
step will be important because of the unique
combinations of anthropogenic factors that are
inﬂuencing these habitats and the health consequences
for humans living in the surrounding terrestrial
matrix in terms of pathogens, disease vectors,
and pollutants. Indeed, there is a general lack of
comparable studies that might enable us to test for the
homogenization of urban freshwater ecosystems. 74
While we generally consider urban ponds to be
‘ponds in urban environments’, it could be that
190 © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Volume 1, March/April 2014

we need to consider these habitats as no-analog,
qualitatively different ecosystems from those ponds
that exist in other landscape contexts. Also, different
anthropogenic pressures act on different components
of the ecosystem: invasive ﬁsh act as top predators,
eutrophication inﬂuences primary production, and
habitat isolation acts on macroinvertebrates and
amphibians. Second, there are a number of species
that persist despite intensive human activity. Examples
include the damselﬂyIschnura elegans, which tolerates
and thrives in urban areas even when other
Odonata are highly sensitive to pollution and pond
morphology,40 the goldﬁsh Carassius auratus,w h i c h
is also tolerant of degraded water bodies, 74 and the
mallard Anas platyrhynchos, urban populations of
which show genetic differentiation from nearby rural
populations.75 In the past these eurytopic species have
been considered as generalists that can survive a range
of conditions, and attention has been focused on
why excluded species are unable to persist in urban
environments. However, a greater consideration of
the drivers of ‘commonness’ is called for. In particular,
where biodiversity is reduced through the exclusion
of a portion of the species pool, this magniﬁes
the ecological role of those common species that
remain.76 What are the traits that enable species to
occur in a wide range of environments and what
are the consequences of declines in the abundance of
these common species for biodiversity and ecosystem
function?
Function
Ecological Function
Ponds act as more than just containers of biodiversity,
providing a range of ecosystem services.77 Ponds
constitute a network of distributed, discrete habitat
patches sometimes referred to as the ‘pondscape’.78
This network can function in two ways depending
on the focal species. For amphibians, for example,
ponds can function as ‘stepping stones’ across a
matrix of inhospitable terrain79 where individual
ponds might be unsuitable for breeding but are vital
temporary habitats during onward dispersal across
the terrestrial matrix.80–82 This function in particular
was highlighted by the European Habitats Directive
(98/83/EC), which points out that ‘... stepping stones
(such as ponds or small woods), are essential for the
migration, dispersal and genetic exchange of wild
species’. For other species, the discrete nature of
the aquatic environment within a terrestrial matrix
creates a classical metapopulation situation, 83 where
most or all ponds are suitable habitat and dispersal
occurs between generations. The introduction of the

__data__.text:
WIREs Water Ecology and biodiversity of urban ponds
Natura2000 network across EU member states has
further emphasized the need to consider ecological
coherence in conservation planning, providing a
strong motivation for the creation and protection
of habitats such as ponds. Complementing existing
network corridors by reducing the barrier effects of
urban areas can be accomplished by enhancing habitat
connectivity within those areas, for example, through
the creation and maintenance of a high-quality urban
pondscape.
Water Management and Treatment
Within an urban context, ponds are frequently used
to control stormwater ﬂow.84 This practice (called
‘sustainable urban drainage’) is mandatory under
building regulations in a number of countries and
results in heavily managed wetlands.85 Studies of these
wetlands have shown that while there is considerable
variation in community structure, these water bodies
can provide a surprising amount of diversity to
a regional species pool, 53 particularly when other
habitats are rare. 43,44 This run-off from human-
modiﬁed land brings with it heavy metals and nutrients
that can be retained by ponds 86,87 (Box 1). The
retention of nutrients within agricultural landscapes
leads to extremely high productivity and associated
levels of carbon sequestration that exceed those in any
other habitat on the planet.88
BOX 1
BIOREMEDIATION USING WETLAND
BIOTA
Among the many ecosystem services provided
by urban water bodies, bioremediation has been
identiﬁed as a plausible alternative to chemical
ﬁltering to remove heavy metals.92 Wetlands
can remove heavy metals and nutrients from
run-off either through binding in sediments93
or accumulation in plant tissues. 92 Certain
applications (such as heavy metal removal)
require harvesting of plants in which metals
are accumulated, providing a potential source
of biomass for use as fuel.94 However, there is
evidence that preexisting microbial communities
may have the ability to cleanse contaminated
sites without interference in cases such as
petroleum spills.95 Recent advances in genetic
engineering could lead to the application of
such microorganisms in other situations.96 A
more complex issue within urban environments
is the use of benthic sampling to monitor water
or sediment quality, in which many systems of
habitat monitoring make use of ‘reference sites’.
The difﬁculty in urban environments is that a
wide range of aspects of biological functioning
can be inﬂuenced by urban processes, making
it difﬁcult to tell whether, for example, water
quality is driving the variation in biological
communities. A solution to this problem would
require either (1) the identiﬁcation of new
reference sites that are indicative of the types
of water bodies found in urban environments
but which are minimally impaired relative to
other urban wetlands, or (2) the quantiﬁcation
of impact within a region such that comparisons
are made internally and reﬂectrelative quality
rather than reference to an absolute standard.97
Social Function
A further set of functions that differ from the
direct and indirect uses described above relate to
less tangible processes. Ponds certainly contain a
greater proportion of the landscape-level biodiversity
than other comparable habitats, as discussed above,
and therefore allow humans to contribute to the
conservation of endangered species that have speciﬁc
habitat requirements.14 Urban ponds also contribute
to green space in cities that may play a role in
improving individual and community health and
well-being.89 Furthermore, there is a traditional and
cultural link with wetlands that has been lost in
many areas of the developed world but that is being
increasingly encouraged as a focus in the conservation
of wetlands.90 This area in particular drives a need
for interdisciplinary research incorporating both the
physical/chemical/biological sciences and the social
sciences in order to ensure that information about, and
conservation of, wetlands is presented in such a way as
to appeal to past or present cultural associations with
those habitats.90 Through a deeper understanding of
the social function and value of wetlands and other
ecosystems we can not only tailor our message to
particular communities but also gain an insight into
whether or how those cultural associations need to
be shifted in order to ensure community buy-in to
sustainable development.91
THE CHALLENGES OF URBAN
BIODIVERSITY
Pollution
Partly as a result of their proximity to human
activity and partly as a result of their deliberate
use as ﬁlters of the waste from that activity, urban

__data__.text:
Advanced Review wires.wiley.com/water
wetlands tend to accumulate pollutants. Heavy metals
also enter freshwaters through their association
with deicing treatments. The application of road
salt (predominantly NaCl, CaCl2, and MgCl 2)a s
a treatment against ice is a common practice in
many temperate, developed nations (for a review,
see Ref 98). The salt itself causes problems for
amphibian osmoregulation99,100 but also carries with
it heavy metals that accumulate in the tissues of
plants and animals (see Ref 101 for a review). While
we understand the direct effects that salinization of
urban wetlands can have on the constituent biota
through the use of ecotoxicological assays andin
situ biomonitoring, what is less clear are the indirect
effects. For example, in an insightful mesocosm
experiment, Meter et al.102 demonstrated that salt
has an adverse direct effect on zooplankton, reducing
competition for algae, which then increases the size
and developmental rates of amphibians. Once more,
this highlights the need to consider the ecosystem in
its entirety, rather than focusing on a small number of
species or components.
Invasive Species
Out of 891 species listed in the Global Invasive Species
Database (http://www.issg.org/database), 277 (31%)
are associated with urban areas, 395 (44%) are asso-
ciated with water (wetlands, lakes, or water courses),
and 147 are associated with both urban areas and
water (16%, Figure 2). Urban wetlands provide two
means for enhanced invasions. First, large numbers
of species are imported into urban areas (either on
purpose or by accident) creating a high propagule
pressure that facilitates successful invasion.103 Urban
centers are nodes in trade and transport networks,
which act as conduits and end-points for invasive
species104 and provide opportunities for a range of
different introduction pathways.105
Primary taxa that are imported deliberately
into urban areas include ornamental species such as
goldﬁsh and aquatic plants, and pets such as terrapins
and snakes. Particular issues arise when commercial
suppliers of freshwater species misidentify what is
being sold or fail to ensure adequate biocontrol
measures are in place to prevent contamination
with unordered organisms (such as molluscs and
crustaceans).106 The frequency of occurrence of
aquarium species in shops 107 and the degree of
importation of non-native species 108 have been
shown to correlate with the likelihood of a species
establishing in the wild for freshwater and marine
ﬁsh, respectively. Garden plant communities can be
extremely diverse 109 but these diverse communities
FIGURE 2 | Habitat use of 891 invasive species listed in the Global
Invasive Species Database. ‘Other’ (n = 49) includes corals, fungi,
microorganisms, oomycetes, sponges, and tunicates.
often comprise many ornamental, alien species (see
above) and so act as a source for invasives to enter
the surrounding natural or seminatural areas. 110,111
Similarly, the occurrence of non-native ﬁsh in natural
wetlands around urban centers increases with higher
importation rates.112 Deliberate human introductions
of ﬁsh are also strongly implicated through the
release of ornamental ﬁsh or sports ﬁshing 112 and
the increased chances of ﬁnding non-native species
closer to human access points.58
However, a second mode by which urbanization
can facilitate invasive species is through the
disturbance of existing ecosystems. Ehrenfeld113
provided a list of direct impacts from the presence
of humans in or around aquatic environments, which
can be summarized as follows: (1) modiﬁcation of
channels and banks; (2) disturbance from trafﬁc; (3)
presence of pet animals; (4) dumping of rubbish,
and (5) reductions in permeability of surrounding
land. However, as this list suggests, the impacts of
urbanization are a heterogeneous in and of themselves.
Rather than producing a single, invadable habitat
type, human–wetland interactions in urban areas
create a diversity of habitat types that sometimes
favor invasive species.113
Pond Loss
Ponds have been lost across the developed world at a
high rate as their function in agricultural and industrial
settings declined and land was needed for urbanization
or the intensiﬁcation of agriculture. Much of this loss
(50–70%) occurred during the late 19th and early 20th
centuries, and what we witness now is a much-reduced
rate of loss.114 Table 3 gives an international
196 © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Volume 1, March/April 2014

comparison of rates of pond loss, showing that such
rates are similar across different countries and regions.
Pond density is a key predictor of biodiversity, 65
which is unsurprising given the substantial barrier
posed by the urban terrestrial matrix.57 Pond loss,
therefore, poses a far greater risk to the coherence
of pond networks within urban environments than
it does within other land-use contexts, and must
be central to plans for the conservation of species
in urban environments. 69 In some regions, such as
the UK, new initiatives are seeking to create new
ponds to replace those that are lost and those that are
damaged, under the assumption that the restoration
of degraded ponds is expensive and that those sites
will never reach their former quality. 133 However,
this hypothesis has received little empirical attention.
In urban environments, where space is limited, the
restoration of existing ponds may be the only option.
The key factor that will determine whether these pond
creation initiatives can succeed is engagement with
stakeholders such as the mineral extraction industry,
developers, and the general public.
What is interesting is that the only study to
have investigated changes in pond numbers in the
last decade has shown a substantial increase in pond
numbers from 1998 to 2007, mostly as part of the
concerted effort to reverse the declines experienced
in the UK over the past century mentioned above. 124
This pattern of change highlights the dynamic aspect
of the pondscape, where ponds are created and lost
at a much higher rate than is the case for other
habitat types, which needs to be taken into account

Advanced Review wires.wiley.com/water
when designing conservation measures. Conventional
conservation practices tend to focus on particular
sites, but a ‘high-quality pond’ at one time may not
remain high quality (or even continue to exist) in the
long term.19 There is also a lack of understanding
about how to create a new pond. Observational
studies based on preexisting sites suggest that the
key requirements are as follows (summarized from
the ﬁndings in Table 2):
• Avoid vertical walls that prevent amphibians
from exiting the water,39
• Maintain submerged and emergent plant
communities40 with light management,60
• Situate to maximize connectivity with existing
ponds,39,65,45
• Be aware of human access that may inﬂuence
species introductions,112
• Use for functions other than biodiversity, such
as stormwater management, may not reduce
diversity but may inﬂuence the composition of
communities that occur,44
• Plan a variety of pond types, as different
conditions (e.g., ﬁsh/ﬁshless, water chemistry,
and morphology) support different communities
in a wide range of taxa.54,40,43,66,62
The ﬁeld of freshwater conservation would
beneﬁt a great deal from experimental studies
that investigate the accumulation and extent of
biodiversity in networks of newly created ponds of
varying kinds and conﬁgurations to establish best
practice. Such studies should follow the example
of Williams et al.134 in planning, monitoring, and
critically evaluating the success of pond network
creation schemes, although methods would have to
be adapted for urban environments.
ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND
CONFLICTING PRIORITIES
Biodiversity: The Good, the Bad, and the
Ugly
In attempting to encourage aquatic biodiversity in
urban areas, there is a need to consider the potential
impacts of increasing nuisance species. Mosquitoes
are a particular problem, and modiﬁcations of wetland
design to reduce mosquito abundance (e.g., steepening
of banks, removal of vegetation, and increased
water depth135) tend to remove those aspects of the
habitat that promote other elements of biodiversity.17
Mosquitoes bring with them potentially fatal diseases
such as West Nile Virus (transmitted primarily by the
Culex pipiens–restuanscomplex)136 in North America
and Dengue fever (transmitted by Aedes aegypti,a
species adapted to urban environments, and Aedes
albopictus) in southern Europe. 137 A. albopictus in
particular is spreading through Europe,138 and climate
change may increase the latitude at which Dengue
fever can be transmitted to produce seasonal waves
of transmission in southern Europe.139 However,
mosquito production tends to be limited to a small
number of sites, and so monitoring and management
there can reduce the need to homogenize all urban
wetlands.140 Mosquitoes are also fewer in number
when insect predators are present, providing an
additional motivation for enhancing biodiversity in
a broader sense. 136 Other nuisance species may
be more innocuous, such as the loud calling of
the striped marsh frogRana ridibunda.E v e nf o r
harmless animals, the general public holds deep-
seated negative views (and even fear) of biodiversity141
and these views inﬂuence their preference for highly
managed urban green space versus seminatural
areas.142 However, such distaste can be overcome
by gradual introduction of successively ‘more-natural’
sites coupled with outreach and education.143
Aesthetics versus Ecology
Many surveys of residents show that there are
generally positive views of urban wetlands.144–146
However, those wetlands are perceived as more
attractive if they have highly visible mown areas and
a clear view of the water without dense macrophyte
beds,147 suggesting that cultural sustainability needs
to be considered alongside ecological integrity. The
kind of management that seems to appeal most to
residents also reduces biodiversity, for example, the
removal of vegetation from city park ponds vastly
reduces dragonﬂy richness. 40 The challenge, then, is
to appeal to cultural sensitivities that may require
ecological innovation,148 or the provision of both
‘natural’ and ‘formal’ green spaces from which the
public extract different beneﬁts.149
OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE FUTURE
Green Space
Increasing urbanization involves not only the sprawl
of urban margins but also the intensiﬁcation of
land use within already built-up areas and this
reduction in land per unit population leads to
a concomitant reduction in available green space.
It is generally accepted that green space has a
positive effect on a range of health outcomes.89
